(f)  Nothing in this article prohibits conduct against a person because such person has been convicted by any court of competent jurisdiction of the illegal manufacture or distribution of a controlled substance, as defined in section 102 of the Controlled Substances Act (21 USC 802), or as defined in the Tennessee Drug Control Act, compiled in T.C.A. §§ 39-17-401-39-17-432. 
(Code 1981, § 17-3; Code 1998, § 50-28) 
Sec. 46-22. - Discrimination by real estate organizations. 
    It shall be unlawful to deny any person access to, or membership or participation in, any multiple-listing service, real estate brokers' organization or other service, organization or facility relating to the business of selling or renting dwellings, or to discriminate against him in the terms or conditions of such access, membership or participation on account of race, color, religion, sex, handicap, familial status or national origin. 
(Code 1981, § 17-4; Code 1998, § 50-29) 
Sec. 46-23. - Additional remedies. 
    Nothing in this article requires any person claiming to have been injured by an act made unlawful by this article to exhaust the remedies provided in this article or to prevent any such person from seeking relief at any time under the federal civil rights acts or other applicable legal provisions. 
(Code 1981, § 17-7; Code 1998, § 50-32) 
Sec. 46-24. - Interference, coercion or intimidation. 
    It shall be unlawful to coerce, intimidate, threaten or interfere with any person in the exercise or enjoyment of or on account of his having exercised or enjoyed or on account of his having aided or encouraged any other person in the exercise or enjoyment of any right granted or protected by this article. 
(Code 1981, § 17-8; Code 1998, § 50-33) 
Chapters 47-49 - RESERVED 
Chapter 50 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Employment and training of police officers, T.C.A. § 38-8-101 et seq.; minimum statutory standards binding on local government units, T.C.A. § 38-8-105; dismissal for failure to enforce law, T.C.A. § 6-54-402; use of blue flashing emergency lights restricted, T.C.A. § 55-9-414; obstruction of law enforcement, T.C.A. § 39-16-602; authority for arrest, T.C.A. § 40-7-101; resisting arrest, T.C.A. § 40-7-108. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 50-1-50-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 50-19. - Chief of police. 
(a)  There is established the position of chief of police. 
(b)  The chief of police shall maintain and preserve the peace, order and cleanliness of the city. He shall aid in the enforcement of special laws relating to the city and the ordinances thereof and shall enforce all orders of the board of mayor and aldermen relating to the business and duties of his department. The chief of police shall have general charge of the city jail and the prisoners therein. 
(c)  The chief of police is authorized and directed to: 
(1)  Prepare and promulgate such rules and regulations as are necessary and proper to control wrecker services utilized by the police department; provided that such rules and regulations are consistent with the general law of the state, as well as with any applicable provisions of city ordinances. 
(2)  Alter, amend or rescind rules and regulations promulgated under subsection (c)(1) of this section and promulgate such revisions as may from time to time be necessary or desirable. 
(3)  Publish and keep one copy, on file in the office of the city recorder, of all rules, regulations, policies and procedures or any revision thereof, none of which shall become effective until 30 days after publication. 
(Code 1981, § 20-1; Code 1998, § 54-26) 
Sec. 50-20. - Rules and regulations. 
    The police department shall be subject to such rules and regulations as the chief of police may prescribe. 
(Code 1981, § 20-2; Code 1998, § 54-27) 
Sec. 50-21. - Charges against police officers. 
(a)  Charges against a member of the police department, other than those made by the city manager, shall be made to the city manager and verified under oath, except that charges made by any member of the board of mayor and aldermen or the chief of police or city judge need not be in writing or verified. 
(b)  When charges are made, as provided in this section, it shall be the duty of the city manager to file such charges with the recorder, who shall summon such police officer, setting forth in the summons the nature of the charges made, to appear before the city manager and make defense thereto. Three days shall be allowed the accused to prepare his defense. 
(c)  The charges shall be tried and determined by the city manager. If the city manager shall find him guilty, he shall discharge or discipline such officer. 
(d)  The recorder shall issue subpoenas for and the chief of police or some member of the department shall summon such witnesses as may be asked for by either party, and the accused may be represented by counsel. 
(Code 1981, § 20-4; Code 1998, § 54-28) 
Sec. 50-22. - Powers and duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the police to: 
(1)  Prevent crime; 
(2)  Detect and arrest offenders; 
(3)  Suppress riots; 
(4)  Protect the rights of persons and property; 
(5)  Guard the public health; 
(6)  See that nuisances are removed; 
(7)  Restrain disorderly, bawdy and gambling houses; 
(8)  Assist, advise and protect strangers and travelers of the streets or at railroad stations; 
(9)  Enforce all laws and ordinances; 
(10)  Execute all and every manner of process upon persons or property and serve any process issued out of the city court within the city or any and all process issued by any other court; and 
(11)  Do all within their power to enforce the laws and whatever else may be required of them by the board of mayor and aldermen and the laws of the state. 
(Code 1981, § 20-5; Code 1998, § 54-29) 
Sec. 50-23. - License inspection and report. 
    It shall be the duty of each member of the police department, when required by the city recorder, to make a license inspection of the city and report to him all businesses being conducted in the city which are subject to privilege tax. 
(Code 1981, § 20-6; Code 1998, § 54-30) 
Sec. 50-25. - Authority to summon assistance. 
    The chief of police or any member of the police department may call to his assistance as many of the inhabitants of the city as may be necessary to aid him in making an arrest or preventing or quelling any riot, unlawful assembly or breach of the peace, and all persons so called shall be subject to the orders of such police officer while on the duty for which they are called. It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse or fail to obey orders of such police officer when so called by him. 
(Code 1981, § 20-8; Code 1998, § 54-32) 
Sec. 50-26. - Resisting, obstructing police officer. 
    No person shall resist or obstruct a police officer, by force or threat, who is engaged in the discharge of his duty. 
(Code 1981, § 20-9; Code 1998, § 54-33) 
State Law reference- Obstruction of law enforcement, T.C.A. § 39-16-602; resisting arrest, T.C.A. § 40-7-108. 
Sec. 50-27. - Disposition of fees. 
    All fees for official services rendered by any police officer shall be turned into the city treasury. 
(Code 1981, § 20-11; Code 1998, § 54-34) 
Secs. 50-28-50-57. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESERVE POLICE FORCE 

Sec. 50-58. - Composition; employee status. 
(a)  There is created a reserve police force designated the "Kingsport Reserve Police Force" to be composed of not more than 25 voluntary members. Reserve police officers shall be considered as volunteers and special deputies, as defined in T.C.A. § 38-8-101. 
(b)  Reserve police officers shall be under the control and supervision of the chief of police and shall serve at his pleasure. They shall not: 
(1)  Be included under civil service provisions of the personnel rules and regulations; 
(2)  Participate in the Tennessee Consolidated Retirement System; or 
(3)  Be entitled to hearings or grievance procedures upon termination or disciplinary actions. 
(c)  Reserve police officers may receive medical benefits similar to those in the Tennessee Workers' Compensation Act, T.C.A. § 50-6-101 et seq., for injuries incurred while on authorized duty. 
(Code 1981, § 20-21; Code 1998, § 54-61; Ord. No. 4312, § II(20-21), 12-3-1996; Ord. No 5882, § I, 9-1-2009) 
State Law reference- Similar definition, T.C.A. § 38-8-101. 
Sec. 50-59. - Method of appointment and qualifications of membership. 
(a)  No person shall assume duties or hold himself out to be a reserve police officer until after being duly appointed by the city manager and until after taking the oath of office provided for officers of the police department and until the city recorder has been provided with a proper bond as required by law for armed law enforcement officers. 
(b)  Each reserve police officer shall be required to pass the same physical, psychological and battery of general aptitude examinations as a regular line officer of the police department. Each reserve police officer shall be required from time to time to attend such in-service training programs as required and approved by the chief of police. 
(Code 1981, § 20-22; Code 1998, § 54-62; Ord. No. 4312, § II(20-22), 12-3-1996) 
State Law reference- Employment and training of police officers, T.C.A. § 38-1-101 et seq. 
Sec. 50-60. - Parttime assistance of regular police officers. 
    Reserve police officers shall be utilized on a parttime basis for the purpose of assisting regular police officers in civil defense activities or other emergencies, major fires, traffic accidents, traffic control in general, sporting events, parades and such other activities as the chief of police may require in order to support and extend the service capability of regular police officers on routine patrol. 
(Code 1981, § 20-24; Code 1998, § 54-63; Ord. No. 4312, § II(20-23), 12-3-1996) 
Sec. 50-61. - Authority and duties. 
(a)  Generally. The authority of reserve police officers shall be limited solely to those times when authorized to act in such capacity by the chief of police. 
(b)  Firearms; arrests. While serving on official duty as reserve police officers, each such officer shall be authorized to carry firearms in accordance with T.C.A. § 39-17-1315 and as prescribed by rules and regulations promulgated by the chief of police and to make arrests in the same manner as regular police officers. 
(c)  Supervision by other personnel. Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, reserve police officers shall be subject to the direct supervision and control of a fulltime police officer accompanying him on patrol and shall be subject to the direction, control and supervision of all other police personnel in the chain of command of the police department. A reserve police officer who is a retired fulltime state peace officer standards and training (POST) certified law enforcement officer may, at the discretion of the chief of police, function without a fulltime police officer accompanying such reserve officer; provided such reserve police officer completes in-service training each year, but such reserve officer shall be subject to the direction, control and supervision of all police personnel in the chain of command of the police department. 
(Code 1981, § 20-25; Code 1998, § 54-64; Ord. No. 4312, § II(20-24), 12-3-1996; Ord. No. 5669, § I, 4-1-2008) 
Sec. 50-62. - Uniforms, badges and insignia. 
    The chief of police shall prescribe by rules and regulations the uniforms, badges and insignia for reserve police officers and the manner in which the uniforms, badges and insignia shall be worn. It shall be a civil offense for any person not a member in good standing of the reserve police force to wear or use the uniforms, badges or insignia so prescribed by the chief of police. Each occurrence shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1981, § 20-26; Code 1998, § 54-65; Ord. No. 4312, § II(20-25), 12-3-1996) 
Sec. 50-64. - False impersonation. 
    It shall be a civil offense for any person to wear, carry or display a reserve police force identification card or otherwise represent himself to be a member of or connected with the reserve police force, unless he is in fact a member thereof in good standing. Each occurrence shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1981, § 20-28; Code 1998, § 54-67; Ord. No. 4099, § VII, 8-1-1995; Ord. No. 4312, § II(20-27), 12-3-1996) 
State Law reference- Criminal impersonation, T.C.A. § 39-16-301. 
Sec. 50-65. - Abuse of authority or indicia of office. 
    Any reserve police officer may be relieved of reserve officer status by the chief of police, if such reserve police officer: 
(1)  Uses his position at any time when not so authorized; 
(2)  Wears or displays a uniform, insignia or identification at any time when not assigned to duty or when traveling to or from such duty station; 
(3)  Violates any rule, regulation or general order of the police department; or 
(4)  Violates any section of this Code or any provision of state law. 
(Code 1998, § 54-68; Ord. No. 4312, § II(20-28), 12-3-1996) 
State Law reference- Negligent acts or omission by public officers and employees, T.C.A. § 29-20-205. 
Sec. 50-66. - Diminishing or increasing size of force. 
    The chief of police may, by order and with the approval of the city manager, diminish or expand the membership of the auxiliary police force as circumstances require within the limits established in this division. 
(Code 1981, § 20-29; Code 1998, § 54-69; Ord. No. 4312, § II(20-29), 12-3-1996) 
Secs. 50-67-50-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - VOLUNTEER PARKING ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS 

Sec. 50-91. - Authorized. 
    The chief of police is authorized to appoint qualified persons to serve as volunteer parking enforcement officers who shall serve at the pleasure of the chief of police and who shall be under his control and supervision. 
(Code 1998, § 54-96; Ord. No. 4312, § III(20-40), 12-3-1996) 
Sec. 50-92. - Volunteer status. 
    Any person who is appointed as a volunteer parking enforcement officer shall serve on a voluntary basis, and such appointee shall receive no compensation therefor and shall not be deemed to be a city employee for purposes of workers' compensation insurance, retirement eligibility or any other employee benefit. 
(Code 1998, § 54-97; Ord. No. 4312, § III(20-41), 12-3-1996) 
Sec. 50-93. - Duties and authority. 
    The authority of volunteer parking enforcement officers shall be limited solely to the issuance of citations to the city court for violation of chapter 98, article IV, division 1. Such authority shall be limited to periods of time specifically authorized by the chief of police. Volunteer parking enforcement officers shall not carry firearms while on duty nor shall they have the power of arrest. 
(Code 1998, § 54-98; Ord. No. 4312, § III(20-42), 12-3-1996) 
Sec. 50-94. - Waiver of claims. 
    Prior to being appointed as a volunteer parking enforcement officer, the volunteer shall execute and shall have notarized a waiver of claims in a form approved by the city attorney. The waiver shall be retained by the city recorder. 
(Code 1998, § 54-99; Ord. No. 4312, § III(20-43), 12-3-1996) 
Sec. 50-95. - Abuse of authority or indicia of office. 
(a)  Any volunteer parking enforcement officer may be relieved of such volunteer duties by the chief of police if such officer: 
(1)  Uses his position at any time when not so authorized; 
(2)  Wears or displays a uniform, insignia or identification at any time when not assigned to duty or when traveling to or from such duty station; 
(3)  Violates any rule, regulation or general order of the police department; or 
(4)  Violates any section of this Code or provision of state law. 
(b)  It shall be a civil offense for any person to violate this section. 
(Code 1998, § 54-100; Ord. No. 4312, § III(20-44), 12-3-1996) 
State Law reference- Negligent acts or omission by public officers and employees, T.C.A. § 29-20-205. 
Secs. 50-96-50-118. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SCHOOL CROSSING GUARDS 

Sec. 50-119. - Appointment; part-time employment. 
    The chief of police is authorized to appoint qualified persons to serve as school crossing guards. Such persons shall be parttime employees of the city and shall work under the direction of the chief of police. 
(Code 1998, § 54-126; Ord. No. 4302, § I(20-40), 11-19-1996) 
Sec. 50-120. - Qualifications and uniforms. 
    School crossing guards shall wear uniforms as designated by the chief of police. The chief of police shall establish minimum standards for employment and shall establish rules and regulations for the duties as assigned. 
(Code 1998, § 54-127; Ord. No. 4302, § I(20-42), 11-19-1996) 
Sec. 50-121. - Duties. 
    School crossing guards shall be limited to service at designated school crossings as established by the department of education, the chief of police and the transportation department. The authority of school crossing guards shall be limited to monitoring designated school crossings during days when schools are in session and during the hours when school children are going to or returning from public schools. Such hours shall be established by the chief of police and the department of education. 
(Code 1998, § 54-128; Ord. No. 4302, § I(20-41), 11-19-1996) 
Chapters 51-53 - RESERVED 
Chapter 54 - LIBRARY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- State library system, T.C.A. § 10-1-101 et seq.; libraries in counties, cities and towns generally, T.C.A. § 10-3-101 et seq.; library boards, T.C.A. § 10-3-103; preservation of municipal public records, T.C.A. § 10-7-701 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Created. 
    There is created a city library. 
(Code 1981, § 21-1; Code 1998, § 58-1) 
Sec. 54-2. - Failure to return materials. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to detain or fail to return to any public library any book, periodical, map, newspaper, plate, engraving, magazine, pamphlet, manuscript, picture, clipping, phonograph record, motion picture film, black and white or color slide film or film strip, tape, cassette or other property belonging to any public library provided for the public education, use and welfare of the citizens in the city and community, after the lapse of 30 days from the date of posting by certified mail, a notice addressed to such person at the last address furnished the public library. 
(b)  Such notice may be given at any time after the date for which such person should have returned the loaned property in accordance with the rules of such public library. However, no penalty shall be imposed when restitution of value shall have been made prior to the expiration of the 30-day period or in any case where the return of any library property enumerated in this section has been rendered impossible by cause beyond the control of the borrower. 
(Code 1981, § 21-2; Code 1998, § 58-2) 
Sec. 54-3. - Using fictitious name or address. 
    It shall be an offense to give a fictitious or incorrect name or address at any public library in order to obtain possession or use of any library property or services. 
(Code 1981, § 21-3; Code 1998, § 58-3) 
Sec. 54-4. - Defacing property. 
    It shall be an offense for any person to cut, write upon, injure, deface, tear or destroy any library property. 
(Code 1981, § 21-4; Code 1998, § 58-4) 
Secs. 54-5-54-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC LIBRARY COMMISSION 

Sec. 54-27. - Created. 
    There is created a public library commission. 
(Code 1981, § 21-16; Code 1998, § 58-31) 
Sec. 54-28. - Composition; filling vacancies; compensation. 
(a)  The public library commission shall have the composition required by T.C.A. § 10-3-103. 
(b)  If a vacancy occurs on the commission occasioned by death, resignation or inability or refusal of a member to serve, the vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term by appointment by the mayor. 
(c)  The members of the commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1981, § 21-17; Code 1998, § 58-32) 
Sec. 54-29. - Officers. 
    The members of the public library commission shall meet in regular session and organize each year by electing from their number a chairperson, vice-chairperson and a secretary. Each person so elected shall hold office for one year or until his successor is elected by the commission and qualifies. 
(Code 1981, § 21-18; Code 1998, § 58-33) 
Sec. 54-30. - Meetings. 
    The public library commission shall meet in regular session at least once each month, the time and place to be selected by vote of the members. It shall be the duty of the chairperson to preside over all meetings of the commission. In the absence of the chairperson, the vice-chairperson shall preside. Any meeting other than a regular meeting may be called by the chairperson or by any four members. 
(Code 1981, § 21-19; Code 1998, § 58-34) 
Sec. 54-31. - Quorum. 
    Four members of the public library commission present at a meeting shall constitute a quorum. 
(Code 1981, § 21-20; Code 1998, § 58-35) 
Sec. 54-32. - Record of proceedings. 
    The secretary of the public library commission shall keep a record of all proceedings of the commission. 
(Code 1981, § 21-21; Code 1998, § 58-36) 
Sec. 54-33. - Functions. 
    The public library commission shall serve in an advisory capacity and shall prescribe rules and regulations for the conduct, control, government and operation of the city library. Such rules and regulations shall not be effective until approved by the city manager. 
(Code 1981, § 21-22; Code 1998, § 58-37) 
Sec. 54-34. - Budget. 
    The public library commission shall submit to the city manager, in accordance with the budget calendar, a proposed library budget. 
(Code 1981, § 21-23; Code 1998, § 58-38) 
Sec. 54-35. - Grants, gifts, devises and bequests. 
    Any gift, bequest or contribution made for the use of the public library shall be deposited with the city treasurer and held by him in trust, to be kept separate from all other city funds, and shall be disbursed only upon direction of the public library commission, with the approval of the board of mayor and aldermen. 
(Code 1981, § 21-24; Code 1998, § 58-39) 
Secs. 54-36-54-58. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ARCHIVES 

Sec. 54-59. - Established. 
    There is created and established the archives of the city as a division within the department of library and archives. 
(Code 1981, § 21-40; Code 1998, § 58-66) 
Sec. 54-60. - City archivist to be designated by city manager. 
    The archives of the city shall be under the direction and supervision of such person as may be designated from time to time by the city manager, referred to in this article as the city archivist. 
(Code 1981, § 21-41; Code 1998, § 58-67) 
Sec. 54-62. - Establishment of fees. 
    The board of mayor and aldermen may from time to time adopt a schedule of fees for: 
(1)  The copying of documents; 
(2)  The reproduction of photographs, maps, etc.; 
(3)  Time spent to search for any other material; or 
(4)  Any other service appropriately rendered through the archives. 
(Code 1981, § 21-43; Code 1998, § 58-69) 
Sec. 54-63. - Placement of city records. 
    The city recorder may, in consultation with the city archivist and records manager, arrange for the transfer of permanent, nonessential city records meeting the criteria of archival material after appraisal by the city archivist. 
(Code 1981, § 21-44; Code 1998, § 58-70) 
Sec. 54-64. - Private contributions. 
    The city may accept donations of historically significant material from private citizens or businesses, consisting of but not limited to diaries, papers, books, pamphlets, letters, photographs, memorabilia, maps, drawings, paintings, historical materials or other documents relating to the political, economic, social or cultural history of the city or its geographic area, if the city archivist deems such material suitable and appropriate pursuant to established policies and procedures approved by the city manager. 
(Code 1981, § 21-45; Code 1998, § 58-71) 
Sec. 54-65. - Standards for donations. 
    Donations of materials to the city archives shall only be accepted by the city upon agreement of the donor to the following: 
(1)  The donor shall agree in writing that the city, its officers and employees shall have no liability for improper or illegal use by a third party of any material donated under the agreement or for violation of any copyright or other condition or covenant, notwithstanding subsection (2) of this section. The city shall take reasonable precautions to prevent illegal or improper use of, or violation of any condition or covenant placed on any donated materials, but shall not be responsible for any use by third parties. 
(2)  Every donor shall consent in writing to one of the three following provisions for any donation or gift: 
a.  All material included in the bequest is donated without any restriction or reservation. Absolute control and complete rights are conveyed to the city, and no express or implied rights are retained by the donor. 
b.  All material included in the bequest is donated with the single restriction that no item or group of items may be used in any advertisement for any company, product or service without the express written consent of the donor, his heirs or assigns. With the exception of the foregoing, absolute control and complete rights are conveyed to the city, and no other express or implied rights are retained by the donor. 
c.  All material included in the bequest is donated with the restrictions that no item or group of items may be used in any advertisement for any company, product or service nor may any item or group of items be made available for publication in any form, in any book or periodical, without the express written consent of the donor, his heirs or assigns. Such material shall be held for research or viewing by the public at large, and no copies may be made or disseminated without the express written consent of the donor, his heirs or assigns. With the exception of the foregoing, absolute control and complete rights are conveyed to the city, and no other express or implied rights are retained by the donor. 
(3)  Any person requesting the right to use any material from the archives, subject to any of the restrictions in subsection (1) or (2) of this section, shall be responsible, at his own cost, for obtaining the written consent of the donor, his heirs or assigns. 
(Code 1981, § 21-46; Code 1998, § 58-72) 
Sec. 54-66. - Disposal of material. 
    No material donated to or placed in the city archives shall be disposed of, by gift or sale, except upon approval by resolution of the board of mayor and aldermen. 
(Code 1981, § 21-47; Code 1998, § 58-73) 
Chapters 55-57 - RESERVED 
Chapter 58 - MANUFACTURED AND MOBILE HOMES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Manufactured homes generally, T.C.A. § 68-126-101 et seq.; Tennessee Manufactured Home Installation Act, T.C.A. § 68-126-401 et seq.; mobile home transport and permits generally, T.C.A. § 55-4-401 et seq.; transporter's liability for damages to streets and other public structures during transport, T.C.A. § 55-4-413; Uniform Standards Code for Manufactured Homes Act, T.C.A. § 68-126-201 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 58-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Independent mobile home means a mobile home that has a toilet and a bathtub or shower. 
    Independent mobile home park means a mobile home park for independent mobile homes. 
    Independent mobile home space means a mobile home space intended to accommodate an independent mobile home. 
    Inspector means the building official or his duly authorized representative. 
    Mobile home means any vehicle or similar portable structure having been constructed with wheels, whether or not such wheels have been removed, or without wheels but designed to be moved on the highway when attached to a suitable wheeled undercarriage, and not meeting the requirements to be classified as a manufactured home, in accordance with T.C.A. § 68-126-202(4). 
    Mobile home park means any plot of ground two acres or more in size which has been planned, improved and approved for placement of mobile homes. 
    Mobile home space means a plot of ground within a mobile home park designed for the accommodation of one mobile home. 
    Multiple dwelling means any structure designed and intended to accommodate more than one family and includes but is not limited to duplex buildings, group houses and apartment buildings. 
    Park means a mobile home park. 
    Permittee means any person holding a permit to operate and maintain a mobile home park under this chapter. 
(Code 1981, § 13-1; Code 1998, § 62-1) 
State Law reference- Mobile home defined, T.C.A. § 55-4-402; manufactured home defined, T.C.A. § 68-126-202. 
Sec. 58-2. - Mobile homes not located in parks. 
(a)  No person shall park or occupy any mobile home on the premises of any dwelling or on any lot which is not a part of the premises of any dwelling, either of which is situated outside an approved mobile home park, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  If a mobile home located upon a lot, otherwise unoccupied by another residence, within the city on or prior to October 14, 1966, or on or prior to its annexation to the city is removed and no mobile home is relocated upon such lot for a period of 90 days after such removal, no mobile home shall thereafter be placed or located on such lot. 
(Code 1981, § 13-3; Code 1998, § 62-2) 
Sec. 58-3. - Parking of mobile homes. 
    Subject to any other limitations and prohibitions provided by chapter 98, pertaining to traffic, no person shall stop, stand or park a mobile home in a street, alley, highway or other public place for longer than one hour. 
(Code 1981, § 13-4; Code 1998, § 62-3) 
Secs. 58-4-58-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MOBILE HOME PARKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-25. - Compliance date for newly annexed areas. 
    Mobile home parks that are located within areas annexed to the city shall comply with this article within two years after the date of such annexation. 
(Code 1981, § 13-16; Code 1998, § 62-31) 
Sec. 58-26. - Location. 
    Mobile home parks shall be located only in R-1MP zoning districts. 
(Code 1981, § 13-17; Code 1998, § 62-32) 
Sec. 58-27. - Inspection. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a mobile home park which has not been inspected for that year by the building official. 
(Code 1981, § 13-19; Code 1998, § 62-33) 
Sec. 58-28. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any person whose application for a construction permit or for a permit to operate a mobile home park is denied shall be notified in writing, specifying the reasons for such denial. If the person receiving the denial so desires, he may have the denial reviewed on appeal by the board of zoning appeals or other appropriate board by filing with the building official a written request within ten days after notice of such denial. Such written request shall specify with reasonable particularity the grounds on which the applicant relies for a reversal of the denial for the issuance of the construction permit or the permit to operate. This appeal will be heard by the board of zoning appeals in the same manner as appeals are heard under chapter 114. 
(b)  Any person aggrieved by an order of the building official granting, denying, renewing or revoking a permit for a mobile home park under this article may file, within ten days after issuance of such order, a written request for a hearing before the board of zoning appeals. The hearing shall be held in accordance with the appeals procedure as set forth in section 114-68. 
(c)  Any decision of the board of zoning appeals granting, denying, renewing or revoking any permit under this article may be reviewed by a common law writ of certiorari by the procedure contained in section 114-71. 
(Code 1981, § 13-20; Code 1998, § 62-34) 
Sec. 58-29. - Screening. 
    Where any boundary of a mobile home park directly abuts on property that is improved with a permanent residential building located within 25 feet of such boundary or directly abuts on unimproved property that may, under existing laws and regulations, be used for permanent residential construction, a screen such as a fence, wall or hedge shall be erected and adequately maintained along such mobile home park boundary to shield such park from the residential property, as may be determined to be adequate by the building official. 
(Code 1981, § 13-18; Code 1998, § 62-35) 
Secs. 58-30-58-46. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OPERATING PERMIT 

Sec. 58-47. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a mobile home park without an operating permit from the recorder. 
(Code 1981, § 13-31; Code 1998, § 62-61) 
Sec. 58-48. - Application and fee. 
(a)  The application for the permit required in this division or the renewal of the permit shall be filed with the city recorder and shall be accompanied by a fee as set by the board of mayor and aldermen for each mobile home space in or proposed to be in the park. The application for a permit or a renewal thereof shall be made on printed forms furnished by the city and obtainable from the recorder and shall include the name and address of the owner in fee of the tract; if the fee is vested in some person other than the applicant, a duly verified statement by that person that the applicant is authorized by him to construct or maintain the trailer or tourist park and make the application shall be included. 
(b)  If the original permit is granted on or after July 1 of any year, the permittee shall be required to pay one-half of the annual permit fee for that year. 
(Code 1981, § 13-32; Code 1998, § 62-62) 
Sec. 58-49. - Issuance. 
    Before a permit may be issued pursuant to this division, there must be a favorable recommendation by the building official. 
(Code 1981, § 13-33; Code 1998, § 62-63) 
Sec. 58-50. - Transferability. 
    The permit issued pursuant to this division shall not be transferred until the city recorder has in his possession a letter signed by the building official stating that the mobile home park is in compliance with the applicable sections of this chapter. A person desiring a transfer of the permit shall pay a fee as set by the board of mayor and aldermen. 
(Code 1981, § 13-34; Code 1998, § 62-64) 
Sec. 58-51. - Expiration. 
    The permit issued pursuant to this division shall expire on December 31. 
(Code 1981, § 13-35; Code 1998, § 62-65) 
Sec. 58-52. - Revocation. 
    The building official is authorized to revoke any permit issued pursuant to this division if, after due investigation and hearing, he determines that the holder of the permit has violated any section of this chapter or that any mobile home or mobile home park is being maintained in an unsanitary or unsafe manner or is a nuisance. 
(Code 1981, § 13-36; Code 1998, § 62-66) 
DIVISION 3. - CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 58-78. - Application for construction permits. 
    Prior to any construction, alteration, enlargement or improvement to a mobile home park, an application for the necessary construction permits shall be filed with the building official. 
(Code 1981, § 13-44; Code 1998, § 62-91) 
Sec. 58-79. - Plot plan. 
    In addition to other matters required to be submitted with an application for the necessary permits for a mobile home park, there shall be submitted with the application a complete plot plan drawn to scale which shall show: 
(1)  The location, area and dimensions of the mobile home park; 
(2)  The number, location and size of all mobile home spaces; 
(3)  The location, width and arrangement of roadways and walkways; 
(4)  The location and size of service buildings; 
(5)  Any other proposed structures; and 
(6)  The location of playground areas. 
(Code 1981, § 13-45; Code 1998, § 62-92) 
Sec. 58-80. - Application of technical codes. 
    The provisions of the city building, plumbing, electrical, gas and mechanical codes, including but not limited to their provisions for appeals, shall apply to all work done in a mobile home park. 
(Code 1981, § 13-46; Code 1998, § 62-93) 
Sec. 58-81. - Variance from approved plans and specifications. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any construction, alteration, repair, improvement or enlargement of any mobile home park or any structure therein for which a permit is required that varies in any substantial particular from the approved plans and specifications submitted with the application for a construction permit and that is approved and on which the permit issued is based. 
(Code 1981, § 13-47; Code 1998, § 62-94) 
Sec. 58-82. - Final inspection; certificate of completion; letter required for transfer or renewal of permit. 
    Upon completion of all construction of a mobile home park, the building official shall conduct a final inspection of the premises to determine if all conditions of this chapter have been met, and, if so, a certificate of completion shall be issued. The city recorder shall not issue a permit to operate a mobile home park unless the certificate of completion is presented. Prior to the issuance of a transfer of a permit or a renewal of a permit to operate a mobile home park, the recorder must have a letter from the building official stating that the mobile home park is still in compliance with the applicable requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1981, § 13-48; Code 1998, § 62-95) 
Secs. 58-83-58-107. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SITE REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 58-108. - Electrical outlets. 
    The mobile home park plan shall indicate that an electrical outlet of the kind and type required by the electrical code shall be provided for each mobile home space. 
(Code 1981, § 13-66(g); Code 1998, § 62-121) 
Sec. 58-109. - Water supply. 
    An adequate supply of water for domestic purposes shall be supplied to each mobile home space. 
(Code 1981, § 13-58; Code 1998, § 62-122) 
Sec. 58-110. - Waste and garbage disposal. 
(a)  All liquid waste from showers, toilets, laundries, faucets, lavatories, etc., of a mobile home shall discharge into the sanitary sewer system. 
(b)  Every space designed to serve an independent unit shall be provided with sewer connections which shall comply with the city plumbing code. The sewer connections shall be provided with suitable fittings so that watertight connections can be made. Such connections shall be so constructed as to be closed when not connected and shall be trapped and maintained in an odor-free condition. 
(c)  Sanitary facilities in any unit not connected with a public sewer system by approved pipe connections shall be sealed, and their use is declared unlawful. 
(d)  Each faucet shall be equipped with facilities for drainage of waste and excess water. 
(e)  Each mobile home unit shall be provided with a substantial flytight, watertight, garbage depository from which the contents shall be removed and disposed of at least weekly by the park custodian in a central dumpster unit for collection by the city garbage collection service. Alternatively, each mobile home may have the garbage removed no less than weekly either by a permitted collector of solid waste upon such charges as agreed to by the parties or by the city for a fee established by resolution. 
(Code 1981, § 13-59; Code 1998, § 62-123; Ord. No. 6231, § I, 7-24-2012) 
Sec. 58-111. - Electrical service. 
(a)  A standard electrical service shall be provided for each mobile home space, and the outlets for such service shall be weatherproofed. 
(b)  No electrical power line shall be permitted to lie on the ground. No such power line shall be suspended less than 18 feet above the surface of the ground. 
(c)  All electrical installations and connections shall be in conformance with the requirements of the city electrical code. 
(Code 1981, § 13-60; Code 1998, § 62-124) 
Sec. 58-112. - Fire protection and fire hydrants. 
(a)  Every mobile home park shall be equipped at all times with fire extinguishing equipment in good working order, of such type, size and number and so located within the park as to satisfy applicable reasonable regulations of the fire department. 
(b)  Fire hydrants shall be installed in such manner that a fire hydrant shall be located within 400 feet of each mobile home space. 
(c)  In every mobile home park suitable telephone facilities shall be installed and maintained in a convenient and readily accessible place, prominently marked and designated and kept available for use in giving fire alarms at all times. 
(d)  No open fires shall be permitted at any place within the bounds of the mobile home park, outdoor cooking units excepted. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful to accumulate or store combustible rubbish beneath mobile homes or at any other place within a mobile home park. 
(Code 1981, § 13-61; Code 1998, § 62-125) 
Chapters 59-61 - RESERVED 
Chapter 62 - OFFENSES AND NUISANCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Criminal offenses generally, T.C.A. § 39-11-101 et seq.; criminal procedure generally, T.C.A. § 40-1-101 et seq.; abatement of nuisances, T.C.A. § 29-3-101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 62-1-62-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC HEALTH, SAFETY AND WELFARE 

Sec. 62-19. - Unauthorized boarding or riding on train. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than employees or passengers, to board any train engine, car or train of cars attached to an engine or to stand upon the steps or platform of any passenger car of a train or to ride or attempt to ride upon an engine or car from one point to another. 
(Code 1981, § 22-9; Code 1998, § 66-5) 
Sec. 62-20. - Child bicycle safety. 
(a)  With regard to any bicycle used on a city street or city property, it is unlawful: 
(1)  For any person under the age of 16 years to operate or be a passenger on a bicycle unless at all times when so engaged such person wears a protective bicycle helmet of good fit fastened securely upon the head with the straps of a helmet. 
(2)  For any person to be a passenger on a bicycle unless, with respect to any person who weighs fewer than 40 pounds or is less than 40 inches in height, the person can be and is properly seated in and adequately secured to a restraining seat. 
(3)  For any parent or legal guardian of a person below the age of 12 years to knowingly permit such person to operate or be a passenger on a bicycle in violation of subsection (a)(1) or (2) of this section. 
(4)  To rent or lease any bicycle to or for the use of any person under the age of 12 years unless: 
a.  The person is in possession of a protective bicycle helmet of good fit at the time of such rental or lease; or 
b.  The rental or lease includes a protective bicycle helmet of good fit, and the person intends to wear the helmet, as required by subsection (a)(1) of this section, at all times while operating or being a passenger on the bicycle. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall pay a penalty of $2.00 per incident, plus court costs. It shall be a defense that a protective bicycle helmet or restraining seat has been purchased or provided and its use will cause the bicyclist or passenger or parent or legal guardian to come into compliance with this section. 
(Code 1981, § 16-30; Code 1998, § 66-26; Ord. No. 4602, § I, 11-3-1998) 
Sec. 62-21. - Use of condemned water supply. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use for domestic purposes the water from any creek, spring, well or cistern which has been condemned for such use by the city, county or state health authorities. 
(Code 1981, § 16-26(b); Code 1998, § 66-23) 
Sec. 62-22. - Gambling. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to permit, in any house or tenement in his premises or under his control, any gambling table or gambling device at which any game of chance shall be played for money or property or anything representing such or for any person to bet, win or lose, or play for money or property, either in specie or by means of anything representing such at any such table or device or at any game of chance. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep in his possession any gambling table or gaming device, slot machine, horse race ticket or machine, tip board, baseball or football ticket used for the purpose of gambling or for the enticement of any person to gamble. 
(c)  The city judge shall order burned or destroyed any gambling devices or paraphernalia found in the city. 
(d)  All persons present who are aiding and abetting or ready and consenting to aid and abet in the commission of a violation of this section shall be principal offenders and punished as such. 
(Code 1981, § 16-10; Code 1998, § 66-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, T.C.A. § 39-17-502. 
Sec. 62-23. - Unlawful assembly. 
    It is an offense for two or more persons to assemble in the city with the intent of being unlawfully assembled, and who shall mutually agree to do any unlawful act with force and violence against the property of the city, the person or property of another or against the peace, or to the terror of others, and shall make any movement or preparation therefor, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 16-5; Code 1998, § 66-6) 
State Law reference- Unlawful assembly, T.C.A. § 38-3-101; rioting, T.C.A. §§ 39-17-302, 39-17-303. 
Sec. 62-24. - Disrupting meeting or procession. 
    A person commits an offense if, with the intent to prevent or disrupt a lawful meeting, procession or gathering, the person substantially obstructs or interferes with the meeting, procession or gathering by physical action or verbal utterance. 
(Code 1981, § 16-6; Code 1998, § 66-7) 
Sec. 62-25. - Disorderly conduct. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if the person, in a public place and with intent to cause public annoyance or alarm: 
(1)  Engages in fighting or in violent or threatening behavior; 
(2)  Refuses to obey an official order to disperse issued to maintain public safety in dangerous proximity to a fire, hazard or other emergency; or 
(3)  Creates a hazardous or physically offensive condition by any act that serves no legitimate purpose. 
(b)  A person also violates this section if the person makes unreasonable noise which prevents others from carrying on lawful activities. 
(Code 1981, § 16-7; Code 1998, § 66-8) 
State Law reference- Disorderly conduct, T.C.A. § 39-17-305. 
Sec. 62-26. - Masks and disguises prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to be upon any of the public streets, alleys, sidewalks or parkways or in or upon any of the buildings or adjacent properties used in connection therewith while wearing a mask, false face or while using any other disguise. 
(b)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Persons impersonating other characters, real or fictional, for a lawful purpose; 
(2)  Persons employing the use of disguise as a part of a bona fide theatrical performance, exhibition or parade for the purpose of advertisement or profit; or 
(3)  Children under 16 years of age on Halloween while not engaged in an act otherwise unlawful. 
(Code 1981, § 16-14; Code 1998, § 66-13) 
Sec. 62-27. - Strikes by public employees. 
    No public employees of the city shall strike, sit down, slow down or engage in any cessation or any interruption of work or any other organized or concerted interference of any kind. Any public employee of the city in violation of this section shall be subject to discharge forthwith by the city manager or other city official or board charged with the responsibility under the Charter and this Code of discharging city employees. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the selective discipline of public employees of the city who violate this section. 
(Code 1981, § 16-27; Code 1998, § 66-24) 
State Law reference- Right to work, T.C.A. § 50-1-201 et seq. 
Sec. 62-28. - Camping, sleeping in designated places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to camp, camp out, sleep, lodge or take up residence in any camper, van, bus or other motor vehicle on the public streets or in any park or public place, except locations or sites which are designated for such occupancy and use. 
(Code 1981, § 16-29; Code 1998, § 66-25) 
Sec. 62-29. - Amplified noise from motor vehicles. 
(a)  No person operating or occupying a motor vehicle on any public street, highway, alley, parking lot, or driveway shall operate or permit the operation of any sound amplification system including, but not limited to, any radio, tape player, compact disc player, loudspeaker, or any other electrical device used for the amplification of sound from within the motor vehicle so that the sound is plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet or more from the vehicle. For the purpose of this subsection, the term "plainly audible" means any sound that clearly can be heard, by unimpaired auditory senses based on a direct line of sight of 50 feet or more; however, words or phrases need not be discernible and such sound shall include bass reverberation. 
(b)  This section shall not be applicable to emergency or public safety vehicles, vehicles owned and operated by a municipal or county government or any utility company, for sound emitted unavoidably during a job-related operation, or for school or community sponsored activities, auctioneers or auctioning activities, boats or other watercrafts operated on waters or any motor vehicle used in an authorized public activity for which a permit has been granted by the appropriate agency of a municipal or county government. 
(Code 1998, § 66-27; Ord. No. 5272, § I, 1-18-2005) 
State Law reference- Excessive noise from motor vehicles, T.C.A. § 55-8-193. 
Secs. 62-30-62-46. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 

Sec. 62-47. - Criminal trespass. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, the term "enter" means intrusion of the entire body. 
(b)  A person commits criminal trespass if the person, knowing he does not have the owner's effective consent to do so, enters or remains on property or a portion thereof. Knowledge that the person did not have the owner's effective consent may be inferred where notice against entering or remaining is given by: 
(1)  Personal communication to the person by the owner or by someone with apparent authority to act for the owner; 
(2)  Fencing or other enclosure obviously designed to exclude intruders; or 
(3)  Posting reasonably likely to come to the attention of intruders. 
(c)  It is a defense to prosecution under this section that: 
(1)  The person entered or remained on property that the person reasonably believed to be property for which the owner's consent to enter had been granted; 
(2)  The person's conduct did not substantially interfere with the owner's use of the property; and 
(3)  The person immediately left the property upon request. 
(Code 1981, § 16-16; Code 1998, § 66-15) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, T.C.A. § 39-14-405. 
Sec. 62-48. - Damaging trees. 
    No person shall cut, break or injure any trees on the public streets or sidewalks or on the private premises of another. 
(Code 1981, § 16-19; Code 1998, § 66-17) 
State Law reference- Vandalism, T.C.A. § 39-14-408. 
Sec. 62-49. - Obstructing highway or other passageway. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, the term "obstruct" means to render impassable or to render passage unreasonably inconvenient or potentially injurious to persons or property. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if the person, without legal privilege, intentionally, knowingly or recklessly: 
(1)  Sits on a window ledge or obstructs a highway, street, sidewalk, railway, waterway, elevator, aisle or hallway to which the public or a substantial portion of the public has access or any other place used for the passage of persons, vehicles or conveyances, whether the obstruction arises from the person's acts alone or from the person's acts and the acts of others; or 
(2)  Disobeys a reasonable request or order to move issued by a person known to be a law enforcement officer, a firefighter or a person with authority to control the use of the premises to: 
a.  Prevent obstruction of a highway or passageway; or 
b.  Maintain public safety by dispersing those gathered in dangerous proximity to a fire, riot or other hazard. 
(c)  This section shall in no way whatsoever is construed to prohibit any lawful assembly of one or more persons for the purpose of lawful demonstration or redress or grievances. 
(Code 1981, § 16-20; Code 1998, § 66-18) 
State Law reference- Obstruction or damage to highways, T.C.A. § 54-10-110. 
Secs. 62-50-62-71. - Reserved. 
Sec. 62-72. - Carrying weapons. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry in any manner whatever, with intent to go armed, any razor, dirk, Bowie knife or other knife or like form, shape or size or a pocketknife with blade exceeding four inches in length or a switchblade knife of any size or a sword cane, icepick, slingshot, blackjack, knucks, Spanish stiletto or a fountain pen pistol or gun or like instrument containing a firing pin capable of shooting tear gas or pistol cartridges, except authorized military personnel. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry concealed on or about his person any razor, dirk, Bowie knife or other knife of like form, shape or size or a pocketknife with a blade exceeding four inches in length or a switchblade knife of any size or a sword cane, icepick, slingshot, blackjack, brass knucks, Spanish stiletto or a fountain pen pistol or gun or like instrument containing a firing pin capable of shooting tear gas or pistol cartridges, or any other dangerous weapon. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to any person employed in the Army, Air Force, Navy or Marine Service of the United States or to any officer or police officer while bona fide engaged in his official duties, in the execution of process or while searching for or engaged in arresting criminals, nor to persons who may have been summoned by such officer or police officer in the discharge of his duties and in arresting criminals and transporting and turning them over to the proper authorities or to those fire officials designated pursuant to T.C.A. § 68-102-149. This section shall not apply to any conductor of any passenger or freight train of any railroad while he is on duty. Persons who may be employed in the army, air force, navy or marine service, as stated in this subsection, shall only carry such pistols as are prescribed by the army, air force and navy regulations. 
(Code 1981, § 16-1; Code 1998, § 66-1; Ord. No. 4501, § 1, 4-7-1998) 
State Law reference- Dangerous weapons, T.C.A. § 39-6-1701 et seq.; unlawful carrying of weapons, T.C.A. § 39-17-1307. 
Sec. 62-73. - Discharge of firearms. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, except in the performance of some duty required by law, or by members of a military detail in attendance upon an interment, or upon written approval of the chief of police as hereinafter set out, to discharge any gun, pistol or other firearm in the city, including any instrument that can be loaded with and fire blank cartridges. 
(b)  For the purposes of educational activities, sporting events, special events, or animal control measures, a person may discharge a gun, pistol or other firearm only upon the review and written approval by the chief of police after the submission, by such person to the chief of police, of a written safety plan and projected schedule of those times and days of the week or dates when the activities or events would take place. The chief of police shall act upon the request within ten working days after the filing thereof. If the chief of police rejects the request, a notice of this action shall be provided to the requesting person stating the reasons for denial of the request. 
(c)  Any person aggrieved by a decision of the chief of police under this section shall have the right to appeal the denial of request for an exception to this section to the board of mayor and aldermen. The written notice of appeal shall be delivered to the office of the city manager, prior to 5:00 p.m., within three working days after receipt of notice of rejection from the chief of police. A hearing before the board of mayor and aldermen shall be conducted at its next regularly scheduled meeting. The board of mayor and aldermen shall render its decision no later than three working days after such hearing. 
(d)  To effectuate the purpose of this section, the chief of police is authorized and directed to prepare, promulgate, alter, amend or rescind such rules, policies and procedures as are necessary and proper to control discharge of firearms in the city, provided that such rules, policies and procedures are consistent with the general law of the state, as well as with any applicable provisions of city ordinances. A copy of such shall be sent to the city recorder. 
(Code 1981, § 16-2; Code 1998, § 66-2; Ord. No. 4953, § I, 8-21-2001) 
Sec. 62-74. - Bows, slingshots, airguns and similar devices. 
    No person shall have or use in any street or other public place any bow, crossbow, rubber flippers, slingshot, airgun or other device other than firearms by which shot or other projectiles are cast. No person shall shoot any such device from any premises into the streets. 
(Code 1981, § 16-3; Code 1998, § 66-3) 
Sec. 62-75. - Confiscation and disposal of illegal weapons. 
(a)  Whenever any person arrested by any city officer is found to have on his person or about him in an unlawful manner any prohibited weapon as set forth in T.C.A. § 39-17-1301 et seq., such weapon shall become the property of the city. 
(b)  All weapons so confiscated may be destroyed or otherwise disposed of in accordance with state and federal law. In no event shall such weapon be returned to the person arrested or to any of his relations or friends. 
(Code 1981, § 16-4; Code 1998, § 66-4) 
Secs. 62-76-62-124. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - NUISANCES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- For unsafe and unfit structure nuisances, see chapter 22, article IX. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 62-125. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nuisance means an action of any person in doing an unlawful act or in omitting to perform a duty or in suffering or permitting any condition or thing to be or exist, which act, omission, condition or thing either: 
(1)  Injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of others; 
(2)  Unlawfully interferes with, obstructs or tends to obstruct or renders dangerous for passage any public or private street, highway, sidewalk, stream or drainage; 
(3)  In any way renders other persons insecure in life or the use of property; or 
(4)  Interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of life and property or tends to depreciate the value of the property of others. 
(Code 1981, § 16-60; Code 1998, § 66-56) 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, T.C.A. § 29-3-101. 
Sec. 62-126. - Certain items declared a nuisance, nonconclusive. 
    Placing, depositing, leaving or permitting to be or remain on any public or private property any of the following items is declared to be and shall constitute a nuisance; provided, however, this enumeration shall not be deemed or construed to be conclusive, limiting or restrictive: 
(1)  Rubbish, trash, refuse, junk and other abandoned materials, metals, inoperative automobiles, lumber or other things. 
(2)  Creating or maintaining any condition that provides harborage for rats, mice, snakes and other vermin or that provides breeding places for disease or disease-carrying pests such as flies, mosquitoes, etc. 
(3)  Creating or causing unnecessary or unauthorized noises or annoying vibrations, including animal noises. 
(4)  Creating or causing disagreeable or obnoxious odors and stenches, as well as causing or maintaining the conditions, substances or other causes which give rise to the emission or generation of such odors and stenches. 
(5)  Failing to dispose of the carcasses of animals or fowl within a reasonable time after death. 
(6)  Polluting any public water supply, stream, lake, canal, body of water by placing therein sewage, dead animals, debris, rubbish, trash, industrial wastes or other substances. 
(7)  Creating or causing any accumulation of stagnant water on any lot or piece of ground. 
(8)  Creating or causing dense smoke, noxious fumes, gas, soot or cinders, in unreasonable quantities. 
(Code 1981, § 16-61; Code 1998, § 66-57) 
Sec. 62-127. - Article supplemental to other ordinances. 
    The provisions of this article shall be supplemental to all other city ordinances. 
(Code 1981, § 16-66; Code 1998, § 66-58) 
Sec. 62-128. - Creating or causing nuisance prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit, maintain or allow the creation or maintenance of a nuisance. 
(Code 1981, § 16-62; Code 1998, § 66-59) 
Secs. 62-129-62-154. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NUDITY OR SEXUAL ACTIVITIES IN PUBLIC PLACES 

Sec. 62-155. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public place. 
(1)  The term "public place" means any location frequented by the public, or where the public is present or likely to be present, or where a person may reasonably be expected to be observed by members of the public. The term "public place" includes, but is not limited to: streets, sidewalks, parks, beaches, business and commercial establishments (whether for profit or not for profit and whether open to the public at large or where entrance is limited by a cover charge or membership requirement), bottle clubs, hotels, motels, restaurants, nightclubs, country clubs, cabarets and meeting facilities utilized by any religious, social, fraternal or similar organizations. 
(2)  The term "public place" does not include premises used solely as a private residence, whether permanent or temporary in nature. 
(Code 1998, § 66-70; Ord. No. 4339, § 1, 2-4-1997) 
Sec. 62-156. - Unlawful conduct in establishments serving food or alcoholic beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to appear in any public place, or upon the premises thereof, where food, wine, beer or other alcoholic beverages are offered for sale, consumed, possessed or are otherwise present, including the practice commonly known as brown bagging, and: 
(1)  To publicly or openly perform acts, or simulated acts, of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation, or any other sexual acts prohibited by law; 
(2)  To publicly or openly engage in the actual or simulated touching with the hand, facial area or mouth, or caressing, or fondling of the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals; 
(3)  To publicly or openly engage in the actual or simulated display to public view of any portion of the human male or female genitals, pubic area or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering; the display of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of the areola, or the showing of covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state; 
(4)  To publicly or openly wear or use any device or covering, exposed to public view which simulates any portion of the human male or female genitals, pubic area or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering, the display of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of the areola, or the showing of covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state; 
(5)  To employ, use or allow any person in the sale or service of food, wine, beer or other alcoholic beverages while such person is publicly or openly unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose to view any portion of the human male or female genitals, pubic area or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering; the display of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of the areola; or the showing of covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state; 
(6)  To employ, use or allow the services of any hostess or other person to mingle with patrons while such hostess or other person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose to view any portion of the human male or female genitals, pubic area or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering, the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of the areola, or the showing of covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state; 
(7)  To publicly or openly permit any person to use artificial devices or any inanimate objects to depict any prohibited activities described in subsections (1) through (6) of this section; or 
(8)  For the owner of the property, or the owner of any business operated thereon, or any employee thereof to knowingly allow or permit any person to remain in or upon the premises who is exposing to public view any portion of the human male or female genitals, pubic area or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering, the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of the areola, or the showing of covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state. 
(Code 1998, § 66-71; Ord. No. 4339, § 1, 2-4-1997) 
State Law reference- Prohibited sexual conduct and representations in establishments holding alcohol licenses, T.C.A. § 57-4-204. 
Sec. 62-157. - Unlawful displays or acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to appear in any public place, or upon the premises thereof, where wine, beer or other alcoholic beverages are offered for sale, consumed, possessed or are otherwise present, including the practice commonly known as brown bagging, and to publicly or openly show films, videotapes, laser discs, CD ROMS, electronic reproductions or other visual reproductions that involve movement depicting any of the following: 
(1)  Acts or simulated acts of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law; 
(2)  Any person being touched, caressed or fondled on the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals; 
(3)  Scenes wherein a person displays the vulva, the anus or the genitals; or 
(4)  Scenes wherein artificial devices or inanimate objects are employed to depict, or drawings are employed to portray, any of the prohibited activities described in this section. 
(Code 1998, § 66-72; Ord. No. 4339, § 1, 2-4-1997) 
State Law reference- Prohibited sexual conduct and representations in establishments holding alcohol licenses, T.C.A. § 57-4-204; indecent exposure, T.C.A. § 39-13-511. 
Sec. 62-158. - Investigation and enforcement. 
    The police department of the city is hereby empowered to conduct investigations into alleged violations of the provisions of this division, T.C.A. § 57-4-204 and any other applicable law or ordinance; and such department shall report such violations to the appropriate authorities for such action as may be proper. 
(Code 1998, § 66-73; Ord. No. 4339, § 1, 2-4-1997) 
Sec. 62-159. - Display of televised performances. 
    Nothing contained in this division shall be construed to prohibit the broadcast or display of any television program subject to regulation by the Federal Communications Commission of the United States. 
(Code 1998, § 66-74; Ord. No. 4339, § 1, 2-4-1997) 
Sec. 62-160. - Acts declared to be a public nuisance. 
    Violation of any provision of this division is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. Imposition of the penalties set out herein shall be in addition to and supplemental of the right to seek injunctive relief to abate the nuisance from an appropriate court. 
(Code 1998, § 66-75; Ord. No. 4339, § 1, 2-4-1997) 
Secs. 62-161-62-188. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MINORS 

Sec. 62-189. - Curfew for minors. 
(a)  Except as otherwise specifically provided in this section, a child who has not reached the age of 16 years shall not loiter, idle, wander or play in or upon the public streets, highways, alleys, parks, playgrounds, schools or public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement and entertainment, vacant lots or other unsupervised places between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 5:00 a.m. This prohibition shall not apply to a child exercising rights protected by the First Amendment of the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech and the right of assembly. 
(b)  It is unlawful for the parent or guardian of a child to permit the child to violate this section. 
(c)  Prosecution under this section shall be subject to defenses for a child: 
(1)  Accompanied by a parent or guardian or other adult person who has been delegated care and custody of the child by the parent or guardian; 
(2)  On an emergency errand or legitimate business directed by his parent or guardian or other adult person who has been delegated care and custody of the child by the parent or guardian; 
(3)  In the process of going to or returning home from lawful employment; 
(4)  Traveling through the city in the course of interstate travel; 
(5)  Attending or returning from a school or social function for which he has written permission in his possession from his parent or guardian. The written permission shall be specific as to the date, time and place for which it is effective; 
(6)  On the sidewalk in front of his residence or the residence of a next-door neighbor, unless there has been a disturbance reported in connection with the minor's presence. 
(Code 1981, § 16-24; Code 1998, § 66-21) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to define, prohibit, abate, suppress, prevent and regulate all acts, practices, conduct, businesses, occupations, callings, trades, uses of property and all other things whatsoever detrimental, or liable to be detrimental, to the health, morals, comfort, safety, convenience or welfare of its inhabitants, T.C.A. §§ 6-2-201(22), 6-19-101(22) and (33), 6-33-101; curfews during civil emergencies, T.C.A. § 38-9-103. 
Secs. 62-190-62-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SMOKING REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 62-211. - Smoking on city-owned property. 
(a)  The city manager may promulgate rules governing smoking on city-owned property controlled by the board of mayor and aldermen, subject to the provisions of state law, including the designation of smoking areas outside of city-owned facilities. 
(b)  Any person violating the rules when published by making a copy of such rules available in the office of the city recorder, the office of the city manager and the public library shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, is punishable under the city's general penalty clause or other applicable laws. Additionally, an employee failing to follow such rules, whether posted in the locations proscribed in subsection (a) of this section or not, is subject to corrective action, including termination from employment. 
(Ord. No. 5610, § 1(2-616), 10-16-2007) 
Sec. 62-212. - Aquatic center; smoking prohibited. 
    Pursuant to the authority provided in Public Chapter No. 847 of the Public Acts of the 109 th General Assembly, smoking is prohibited anywhere on the grounds of the city's aquatic center, including, but not limited to, inside the building, the outdoor swimming areas, sidewalks, roads and parking areas. 
    Any person violating this section shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction shall be penalized $50.00 for each offense. In addition, pursuant to section 30-25 of the Kingsport City Code, court costs shall be imposed. The imposition of a penalty hereunder shall be supplemental to any other action, such as the taking of any remedial or injunctive action, or any other legal or equitable relief or enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 6586, § I, 6-21-2016) 
Secs. 62-213-62-232. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ELECTRONIC SMOKING DEVICES 

Sec. 62-233. - Electronic smoking devices; prohibited use on city property. 
(a)  Electronic smoking device, includes, but is not limited to, vaporizers, vape pens, hookah pens, electronic cigarettes, e-pipes, other electronic nicotine delivery systems, electronic smoking devices or other similar devices designed to deliver nicotine, flavored substances or other substances through a vapor exhaled by the user having a smoke-like appearance similar to a cigarette. 
(b)  The board finds based on information from the Federal Drug Administration, the National Institute of Health on Drug Abuse and other studies that electronic smoking devices can be a danger to a person's health. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says research suggests nicotine is as addictive as drugs such as cocaine or heroin. The CDC also says aerosol from these devices is not harmless water vapor and can be potentially harmful to health and that adult nontobacco users should not be exposed to secondhand aerosol from these products. The board further finds that to protect the public health the use of such devices should be limited in city owned, leased or controlled buildings and certain other places. 
(c)  It shall be an offense for any person to use an electronic smoking device in or on: 
(1)  Any building owned, leased or controlled by the city or within twenty-five [feet] of any entrance or exit or a greater distance, if such distance is posted on the entrance or exit door of such building; 
(2)  Any place owned, leased or controlled by the city where smoking tobacco is prohibited by state law; or 
(3)  Any other area, including an outdoor area, owned, leased or controlled by the city when the area is posted with a sign that use of an electronic smoking device is prohibited. 
(d)  Any person violating this section shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction shall be penalized $50.00 for each offense. In addition, pursuant to section 30-25 of the Kingsport City Code, court costs shall be imposed. The imposition of a penalty hereunder shall be supplemental to any other action, such as the taking of any remedial or injunctive action, or any other legal or equitable relief or enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 6587, § I, 6-21-2016) 
Chapters 63-65 - RESERVED 
Chapter 66 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority for local governments to purchase land areas for park purposes, T.C.A. § 11-3-106; authority of municipality to prohibit carrying of firearms within public parks, T.C.A. § 39-17-1311; conditions for annexation of state park or state natural areas by municipalities, T.C.A. § 6-51-120; municipal authority to make improvements by special assessments, T.C.A. § 7-32-101; municipal recreation systems, T.C.A. § 11-24-101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 66-1-66-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 66-19. - Authority to establish fees and charges. 
    The board of mayor and aldermen shall have the authority to establish by resolution fees and charges for the use of city parks, recreational facilities and programs. 
(Code 1998, § 70-26) 
Secs. 66-20-66-41. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DIRECTOR 

Sec. 66-42. - Position established; duties. 
    There is established the position of parks and recreation director who shall report to the city manager and whose duties shall be to: 
(1)  Plan for the recreational needs of the city and recommend programs, facilities and sites to the parks and recreation advisory committee; 
(2)  Schedule and supervise recreation programs and activities; 
(3)  Supervise maintenance of the facilities and equipment of the parks and recreation department; 
(4)  Supervise employees and volunteers of the department; 
(5)  Provide rules and regulations to control the conduct of patrons and employees while they are upon the park or recreational sites of the city or participating in department programs; 
(6)  Manage department finances in compliance with the Charter, this Code and accounting policies and procedures established by the city recorder; and 
(7)  Perform such other duties and responsibilities as may be assigned by ordinance or by the city manager. 
(Code 1981, § 2-124; Code 1998, § 70-51) 
Secs. 66-43-66-72. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

Sec. 66-73. - Composition; appointment; filling vacancies; compensation. 
(a)  The parks and recreation advisory committee shall be composed of nine members. In addition the city manager shall designate ex officio members. 
(b)  The appointive members shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the board of mayor and aldermen and shall serve for three years. If a vacancy occurs among appointive members, the vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term in the manner provided in this section for original appointments. 
(c)  Any appointive member of the committee with unauthorized absences from four consecutive meetings or from six total regular meetings within a 12-month period shall be deemed to have resigned from the committee. A successor shall be appointed to fill the vacancy as provided in this section. 
(d)  Members of the committee and all standing subcommittees shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1981, § 18-2; Code 1998, § 70-76; Ord. No. 4775, § I, 6-6-2000) 
Sec. 66-74. - Officers. 
    Each year the parks and recreation advisory committee shall select from its appointive members a chairperson, a vice-chairperson and a secretary. The chairperson shall serve as the presiding officer and shall assign duties and responsibilities to committee members. The vice-chairperson shall serve as chairperson during absences of the chairperson. The secretary shall maintain a record of the proceedings at meetings of the committee. 
(Code 1981, § 18-3; Code 1998, § 70-77) 
Sec. 66-75. - Quorum 
    A quorum of the parks and recreation advisory committee shall consist of not less than four appointive members. 
(Code 1981, § 18-4; Code 1998, § 70-78) 
Sec. 66-76. - Meetings. 
    The parks and recreation advisory committee shall meet not less than once each month at a time and place approved by the committee. Special meetings may be called by the chairperson or by a majority of the appointive members of the committee upon 24 hours' notice to all members of the committee. 
(Code 1981, § 18-5; Code 1998, § 70-79) 
Sec. 66-77. - Study and recommendations of recreational needs of city. 
(a)  The parks and recreation advisory committee shall study the parks and recreation needs of the community and recommend to the board of mayor and aldermen recreational programs, facilities and special equipment and sites needed or desirable for use in occupying the leisure time of the citizens of the city. 
(b)  The parks and recreation advisory committee shall, as needed, develop special standing subcommittees.
