Structure, purpose, tenure and functions of each standing subcommittee shall be determined by the parks and recreation advisory committee. Standing subcommittee membership appointments shall be made by the parks and recreation advisory committee and shall be approved by the mayor. Membership of each standing subcommittee shall include at least one parks and recreation advisory committee member. 
(c)  The parks and recreation advisory committee shall, as needed, develop for consideration and approval by the mayor and board of alderman policies, rules and regulations for operation of parks, park facilities and programs. 
(Code 1981, § 18-6; Code 1998, § 70-80) 
Secs. 66-78-66-97. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARK OPERATION 

Sec. 66-98. - Camping. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to camp overnight in any public park. However, this section shall not apply to Bays Mountain Park or special programs approved by the director. 
(Code 1981, § 18-7; Code 1998, § 70-106) 
Sec. 66-99. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided, all municipal parks within the city shall be closed between dark and dawn each day of the week, including Sunday, except for programs and activities authorized by the parks and recreation department. It shall be unlawful for any person to be present in or occupy such public parks between such time. 
(b)  General hours of operation for all other parks and recreation facilities shall be determined by the parks and recreation director and approved by the parks and recreation advisory committee. 
(Code 1981, § 18-8; Code 1998, § 70-107) 
Sec. 66-101. - Operation of motor vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motor-powered vehicle, such as but not limited to a motor-driven go-cart, motorcycle, motorbike, motor minibike, motor-powered tricycle and bicycle with attached motor, in or upon any public school grounds, in or upon any public playgrounds or in or upon any public park, either within the city or on property owned by but outside the boundary of the city, except as authorized upon the roadways and parking lots at such public places, designated for vehicular travel or the parking of such vehicle. This prohibition shall not apply to motor-driven or mechanized wheelchairs or mobility devices for disabled individuals. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any single person mobility vehicle wider than 30 inches or three- or four-wheel vehicles longer than 48 inches on any greenbelt or any city trail. All vehicles with a designated capacity of greater than one occupant shall not be allowed on trails, except strollers and bicycles. Motor driven two-wheeled vehicles, are not permitted on any greenbelt or city trail, provided this prohibition shall not apply to electric person-assistive mobility device as defined in T.C.A. § 55-53-101. 
(c)  Subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall not apply to service vehicles operated by the city, emergency vehicles or those vehicles authorized by the parks and recreation director for the purpose of conducting programs, activities or special events, and those vehicles permitted and used in accordance with the federal Americans with Disabilities Act. 
(Code 1981, § 18-10; Code 1998, § 70-109) 
Sec. 66-102. - Projectile weapons or devices. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or be in possession of any firearm, including shotgun, rifle or pistol, except as otherwise provided in T.C.A. § 39-17-1311, bow and arrow, crossbow, rubber flippers, blowgun, slingshot, airgun or other weapon listed in T.C.A. § 39-17-1302 while in or upon or transversing, using or crossing any public park, greenbelt, playground, nature preserve, civic center or building or facility, area or property owned, used or operated by the city for park or recreational purposes, or nature preserve established, provided or controlled by the city, within or without the corporate limits thereof. 
(b)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Duly authorized law enforcement officers within the course and scope of their official duties or to employees of Bays Mountain Park when so authorized by the director of Bays Mountain Park. 
(2)  Only to the extent a person strictly conforms the person's behavior to the requirements of one of the following: 
a.  A person authorized to carry a handgun pursuant to T.C.A. § 39-17-1351; 
b.  A person hunting during the lawful hunting season on lands owned by the city and designated as open to hunting by law or by the appropriate official; 
c.  A person possessing unloaded hunting weapons while transversing the grounds of any public recreational building or property for the purpose of gaining access to public or private lands open to hunting with the intent to hunt on the public or private lands unless the public recreational building or property is posted prohibiting entry; 
d.  A person possessing guns or knives when conducting or attending "gun and knife shows" when the program has been approved by the administrator of the recreational building or property; 
e.  A person entering the property for the sole purpose of delivering or picking up passengers and who does not remove any weapon from the vehicle or utilize it in any manner; or 
f.  A person who possesses or carries a firearm for the purpose of sport or target shooting and sport or target shooting is permitted in the park or recreational area. 
(3)  At any time the person's behavior no longer strictly conforms to one of the classifications in subsection (b)(2) of this section, the person shall be subject to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1981, § 18-11; Code 1998, § 70-110; Ord. No. 6248, § III, 10-16-2012) 
Sec. 66-103. - Hunting of game or wildlife. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Hunting. 
(1)  The term "hunting" means chasing, driving, flushing, attracting, pursuing, worrying, following after or on the trail of, searching for, trapping, shooting at, stalking or lying in wait for any wildlife, whether or not such wildlife is then or subsequently captured, killed, taken or wounded, and every act of assistance to any other person. 
(2)  The term "hunting" does not include stalking, attracting, searching for or lying in wait for wildlife by an unarmed person solely for the purpose of watching wildlife or taking photographs thereof. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to hunt, kill, wound, destroy or ensnare or to attempt to hunt, kill, wound, destroy or ensnare any wildlife or to have in his possession any form of wildlife or parts thereof in or upon any public park, playground or nature preserve established, provided or controlled by the city, within or without the corporate limits thereof. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to an employee of Bays Mountain Park when so authorized by the director. 
(Code 1981, § 18-12; Code 1998, § 70-111) 
Sec. 66-104. - Wheeled vehicle use. 
(a)  Any person who rides upon or operates any bicycle, roller skates, skateboard, wagon, roller blades or similar devices having wheels, but not including wheelchairs, in any park or recreation area shall at all times yield the right-of-way to pedestrians or any person in a wheelchair. 
(b)  The operator of any wheeled device or equipment shall exercise at all times such reasonable prudence as the occasion and circumstances require. Striking, colliding with or causing injury to another person when failing to exercise such reasonable prudence shall constitute an offense. 
(Code 1981, § 18-13; Code 1998, § 70-112) 
Sec. 66-105. - Horses. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except in the performance of a duty required by law, to have a horse, pony, mule or donkey in or upon any park or recreation area except upon written authorization by the city manager. Such authorization may only be granted for a period not to exceed ten days when such use is in connection with a recreational activity sponsored by the city and that is open to the general public, such as but not limited to Fun Fest. 
(Code 1981, § 18-14; Code 1998, § 70-113) 
Sec. 66-106. - Commercial uses. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct any commercial activity in or upon any park or recreation area, except upon written authorization by the city manager. Such authorization may only be granted for a period not to exceed ten days when such use is in connection with a recreational activity sponsored by the city and that is open to the general public, such as but not limited to Fun Fest. 
(Code 1981, § 18-15; Code 1998, § 70-114) 
Sec. 66-107. - Advertising signs. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or erect any poster, sign or banner or to place or erect any sign or device in or upon any park or recreation area, except upon written authorization by the city manager; provided, however, that such restrictions shall not apply to clothing or other articles of attire. Such authorization may only be granted for a period not to exceed ten days when such use is in connection with a recreational activity sponsored by the city, and that is open to the general public, such as but not limited to Fun Fest, and when such advertising, sign or device is directly related to products, services or activities available at that site during the time of such event. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to fenced, walled or enclosed stadiums or arenas where sports activities are usually held and there is a spectator admission charge, nor shall it apply to emblems, insignia, logos or similar devices placed upon uniforms or equipment worn by or used by sports participants. 
(Code 1981, § 18-16; Code 1998, § 70-115) 
Sec. 66-108. - Noise restrictions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate any radio, television, tape player, loudspeaker or other sound amplifying device in or upon any park or recreation area, except upon written authorization by the city manager, in violation of section 62-25. Such authorization may only be granted for a period not to exceed ten days when such use is in connection with a recreational activity sponsored by the city such as but not limited to Fun Fest or when such a public address system or sound amplifying device is used for activities at that site in conjunction with such event. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to fenced, walled or enclosed stadiums or arenas where sports activities are usually held and where there is a spectator admission charge. 
(Code 1981, § 18-17; Code 1998, § 70-116) 
Sec. 66-109. - Destruction of flowers and vegetation. 
    It shall be unlawful to pick, remove, damage or destroy any flower, wildflower, shrub, tree or other vegetation in any park or recreation area. This section shall not apply to city employees or volunteers under direction of city officials in the course of their authorized duties. 
(Code 1981, § 18-18; Code 1998, § 70-117) 
Sec. 66-110. - Feeding waterfowl and shorebirds. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to feed or allow to be fed any waterfowl or shorebirds in or upon any park or recreation area, except in areas designated for this purpose. The director of parks and recreation may designate suitable areas for the feeding of waterfowl and shorebirds. 
(Code 1981, § 18-19; Code 1998, § 70-118) 
Sec. 66-111. - Use of sanitary facilities. 
(a)  No person over the age of six years shall use restrooms located within a park or recreation area when the facility is designated for persons of the opposite sex. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to a person who is assisting a member of the opposite sex when that person, for reasons of physical or mental incapacity, is unable to effect excretory functions without assistance, provided that the assistant takes reasonable steps to safeguard the privacy of any person of the opposite sex who is in or who might enter such premises. 
(Code 1981, § 18-20; Code 1998, § 70-119) 
Secs. 66-112-66-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BAYS MOUNTAIN PARK AND NATURE PRESERVE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 66-136-66-153. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARK COMMISSION 

Sec. 66-154. - Created. 
    There is created a Bays Mountain Park Commission. 
(Code 1981, § 18-40; Code 1998, § 70-171) 
Sec. 66-155. - Composition; appointment; filling vacancies; compensation. 
(a)  The Bays Mountain Park Commission shall be composed of seven members, at least five of whom shall be residents of the city. In addition, the Director of Bays Mountain Park and the Bays Mountain Park Association President shall be ex officio members. 
(b)  The original membership of the commission shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the board for terms of three years. All members shall serve until their successors are appointed and qualify. 
(c)  If a vacancy occurs on the commission, the mayor shall appoint a new member to fill the unexpired term. Such appointment shall be approved by the board. 
(d)  The members of the commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1981, § 18-41; Code 1998, § 70-172) 
Sec. 66-156. - Officers. 
    The members of the Bays Mountain Park Commission shall meet in regular session and organize themselves by electing from their number a chairperson, vice-chairperson and a secretary. Each person elected shall hold office for one year or until a successor is elected and qualified. 
(Code 1981, § 18-43; Code 1998, § 70-173) 
Sec. 66-157. - Meetings; quorum. 
    The Bays Mountain Park Commission shall meet in regular session at least quarterly, and the time and place shall be decided by vote of the members. It shall be the duty of the chairperson to preside over all meetings of the commission. In the absence of the chairperson, the vice-chairperson shall preside. The secretary shall keep a record of all proceedings of the commission. Special meetings may be called by the chairperson or by any four members of the commission. Four members shall constitute a quorum. 
(Code 1981, § 18-44; Code 1998, § 70-174) 
Sec. 66-158. - Functions generally. 
    The Bays Mountain Park Commission, subject to the administrative guidance of the city manager and control of the board of mayor and aldermen, shall be responsible for the operation of Bays Mountain Park within the limits of the Charter and this article and shall prescribe all rules and regulations for the conduct, control, government and operation of the park. 
(Code 1981, § 18-42; Code 1998, § 70-175) 
Sec. 66-159. - Fees and charges connected with operation of park. 
    The Bays Mountain Park Commission shall have the responsibility of determining and proposing to the board of mayor and aldermen for final approval all fees and charges connected with the operation of the park. 
(Code 1981, § 18-45; Code 1998, § 70-176) 
Sec. 66-160. - Gifts; fund. 
    Any monetary gift, bequest or contribution received by the Bays Mountain Park Commission for the use of Bays Mountain Park shall be deposited with the city treasurer and held in trust, to be kept separate from all other funds in a fund identified as the Bays Mountain Park Commission Fund, and such funds shall be disbursed only upon the recommendation of the Bays Mountain Park Commission with the approval of the board of mayor and aldermen. 
(Code 1981, § 18-46; Code 1998, § 70-177) 
Secs. 66-161-66-188. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - NATURE PRESERVE PARK 

Sec. 66-189. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nature preserve means an area of land and water being maintained as nearly as is reasonably possible in its natural condition. 
(Code 1981, § 18-58; Code 1998, § 70-206) 
Sec. 66-190. - Created. 
    Bays Mountain Park is created as a nature preserve. The park shall encompass an area located in Sullivan and Hawkins Counties, more particularly described by ordinance on file in the city recorder's office. 
(Code 1981, § 18-60; Code 1998, § 70-207) 
Sec. 66-191. - Uses and purposes. 
    In order to secure the benefits of an enduring educational resource, Bays Mountain Park shall be held in trust for the following uses and purposes: 
(1)  For scientific research in such fields as ecology, taxonomy, genetics, forestry, pharmacology, agriculture, soil science, geology, paleontology, conservation, environmental education and related fields. 
(2)  For the teaching of biology, natural history, ecology, conservation, environmental education and related subjects. 
(3)  As habitats for plants and animals. 
(4)  As a place of natural interest and beauty. 
(5)  As living illustration of our natural heritage wherein one may observe and experience natural biotic and environmental systems of the earth and their processes. 
(6)  To promote understanding and appreciation of the aesthetic, cultural scientific and spiritual values of such an area by the people of the city. 
(7)  For the preservation and protection of a natural preserve against unnecessary modification or encroachment as a result of occupation, development or other use which would destroy the natural or aesthetic conditions of the area. 
(8)  As an illustration of the cultural heritage of the region. 
(Code 1981, § 18-62; Code 1998, § 70-208) 
Sec. 66-192. - Protection. 
    Bays Mountain Park shall be held in trust for the purposes expressed in section 66-191 and managed and developed in a manner consistent with these purposes. The park shall not be taken for any other use except for other public use after a finding by the Bays Mountain Park Commission of the existence of a public necessity for such public use and with the approval of the board of mayor and aldermen. 
(Code 1981, § 18-63; Code 1998, § 70-209) 
Chapters 67-69 - RESERVED 
Chapter 70 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Transitory vendors, T.C.A. § 62-30-101 et seq.; Pawnbrokers Act of 1988, T.C.A. §§ 45-6-201 et seq., 45-6-219, authority for municipal regulation, limitations, T.C.A. § 45-6-219; Junkyard Control Act of 1967, T.C.A. § 54-20-101 et seq.; scrap metal dealers, T.C.A. § 62-9-101 et seq.; business taxation of antique malls, flea markets, craft shows, antique shows, gun shows and auto shows, T.C.A. § 67-4-710; tax on rental of space to transient dealer or vendor, T.C.A. § 67-6-213. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 70-1. - Bond for soliciting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person soliciting or taking subscriptions or orders for future delivery of periodicals or goods to collect or receive payment in advance of the delivery for such periodicals or merchandise, unless he shall first make a cash or other approved bond in the sum of $100.00 and file the bond with the city recorder and shall obtain a certificate evidencing the approval of such bond. 
(Code 1981, § 111-134; Code 1998, § 74-1) 
Secs. 70-2-70-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREET VENDORS 

Sec. 70-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fire district No. 1 means that area so designated in section 22-1. 
    Food or food products means any type of edible substance or beverage. 
    Goods or merchandise means any items that are not a food product. 
    Stand means any table, showcase, bench, rack, pushcart, wagon or any other device or wheeled vehicle which may or may not be moved without the assistance of a motor and which is not required to be licensed and registered by the department of motor vehicles, used for displaying, storing or transporting of articles offered for sale by a vendor. 
    Vend or vending means to: 
(1)  Sell, offer for sale, expose for sale, solicit offers to purchase; 
(2)  Barter food, goods, merchandise, or services in any public area from a stand, pushcart, motor vehicle, or by a person with or without the use of any other device or other method of transportation; 
(3)  Require someone to pay a fee or to set, negotiate or establish a fee before providing goods or services; 
(4)  Request for donations in exchange for merchandise. 
    Vendor means any person who vends. This includes a vendor who is an employee or agent of another. 
(Code 1998, § 74-27; Ord. No. 5087, § II, 2-4-2003) 
Sec. 70-22. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating this article shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction shall pay a penalty of not less than $25.00 or more than $50.00 for each offense. Each occurrence shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1998, § 74-37; Ord. No. 5087, § II, 2-4-2003) 
Sec. 70-23. - Purpose. 
(a)  The primary purpose of the public streets and sidewalks is for use by vehicular and pedestrian traffic. 
(b)  Regulation of street and sidewalk vending is necessary to ensure safe pedestrian and motor vehicle traffic, and protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(c)  Vending shall be restricted to fire district No. 1 and within this area shall be restricted to specific locations and specific items as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1998, § 74-26; Ord. No. 5087, § II, 2-4-2003) 
Sec. 70-24. - Vending generally allowed by permit only in fire district No. 1. 
    Within fire district No. 1 it shall be unlawful to vend or sell or offer for sale any food, beverage, goods or merchandise on any street or sidewalk without first obtaining a permit. Outside of fire district No. 1, except for the exemptions set out in section 70-28 it shall be unlawful to vend or sell or offer for sale any food, beverage, goods or merchandise on any street or sidewalk in the city. 
(Code 1998, § 74-28; Ord. No. 5087, § II, 2-4-2003) 
Sec. 70-25. - Vendor permit and insurance required; application for permit. 
(a)  No person may vend under this article without first obtaining and having in their possession a vendor permit issued by the city manager or designee, and proof of insurance coverage satisfactory to city. 
(b)  The application for a vendor's permit shall include the following: 
(1)  The full name and home and business address of the applicant, and the name and address of the owner, if other than the applicant, of the vending business along with proof of applicant's identity; 
(2)  A description of the type of food, beverage or goods or merchandise to be sold; 
(3)  The proposed location where the applicant plans to vend; 
(4)  A description and photograph of any stand or any other device to be used in the operation of the business; 
(5)  Three prints of a full-face photograph, taken not more than 30 days prior to the date of the application, of any person who will sell or offer for sale any food, beverage or merchandise on any street or sidewalk within the city; 
(6)  Proof of compliance with state requirements for licensing food vending carts and possession of the required health permits and certifications that he complies with all state and federal laws regarding product vending; 
(7)  Proof of an insurance policy, issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state, protecting the vendor and the city from all claims for damages to property and bodily injury, including death, which may arise from operation under or in connection with the permit. Such insurance shall name the city as an additional insured and shall provide that the policy shall not terminate or be canceled prior to the expiration date without 30 days advance written notice to the city. The policy shall be in an amount not less than $1,000,000.00. A certificate of insurance must be included with the application. 
(c)  Not later than 30 days after the filing of a completed application for a vendor's permit, the applicant shall be notified by the city manager or designee, of the decision on the issuance or denial of the permit. 
(d)  A permit issued pursuant to this section is valid for a period of one year from date of issuance. 
(Code 1998, § 74-29; Ord. No. 5087, § II, 2-4-2003) 
Sec. 70-26. - Denial, revocation, suspension of permit. 
    Any application may be denied and, following a hearing before the city manager, or designee, any permit issued under this article may be suspended or revoked for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud or misrepresentation contained in the application for the permit; 
(2)  Fraud or misrepresentation made in the course of carrying on the business of vending; 
(3)  Conduct of the permitted business in such a manner as to create a public nuisance or constitute a danger to the public health, safety, welfare or morals; 
(4)  The application does not contain the information required by this article; 
(5)  The applicant or vendor has not satisfied the requirement of this article; 
(6)  The issuance or continuance of the permit could endanger public safety; 
(7)  Conduct which is contrary to the provisions of this article; 
(8)  Abandonment of the location by failure to operate a vending operation during at least one-half of the normal business days available; or 
(9)  The failure to comply with other applicable laws. 
(Code 1998, § 74-30; Ord. No. 5087, § II, 2-4-2003) 
Sec. 70-27. - Appeal. 
    Any final decision of the city manager, or designee, may be appealed by an aggrieved party by common law petition for certiorari in the circuit or chancery court of the city, within 60 days after the final decision. 
(Code 1998, § 74-31; Ord. No. 5087, § II, 2-4-2003) 
Sec. 70-28. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any approved participant in any farmer's market. 
(2)  Any approved participant in any cultural arts and crafts show, including Fun Fest and Santa Train Christmas parade. 
(3)  Any approved participant in any special event authorized by the city. 
(4)  Any individual vending newspapers, leaflets, pamphlets, bumper stickers or buttons. 
(Code 1998, § 74-32; Ord. No. 5087, § II, 2-4-2003) 
Sec. 70-29. - Location restrictions. 
    No person may vend: 
(1)  Within ten feet from the outer edge of any entrance of any business, including, but not limited to: 
a.  Doors; 
b.  Vestibules; 
c.  Driveways; 
d.  Outdoor dining area entries; and emergency exits; 
as measured in each direction parallel to the building line, during the hours that any business on the premises is open to the public or to persons having or conducting lawful business within those premises. 
(2)  Within ten feet of any bus stop. 
(3)  Within ten feet of any street corner or marked pedestrian crosswalk. 
(4)  Within 35 feet of any other vendor. 
(5)  In any manner that blocks or obstructs the free movement of pedestrians. 
(Code 1998, § 74-33; Ord. No. 5087, § II, 2-4-2003) 
Sec. 70-30. - Prohibited acts. 
    No vendor shall: 
(1)  Leave any stand unattended; 
(2)  Store, park or leave any stand overnight on any street or sidewalk, or park any motor vehicle other than in a lawful parking place in conformance with city and state parking regulations; 
(3)  Sell food or beverages for immediate consumption unless he has available for public use a litter receptacle which is available for his patrons' use; 
(4)  Leave any location without first picking up, removing and disposing of all trash or refuse remaining from sales made by them; 
(5)  Allow any items relating to the operation of the vending business to be placed anywhere other than in, on, or under the stand from which the business is operated; 
(6)  Set up, maintain or permit the use of any table, crate, carton, rack or any other device to increase the selling or display capacity of his stand where such items have not been described in the application; 
(7)  Solicit or conduct business with persons in motor vehicles; 
(8)  Vend anything other than that which he is licensed to vend; 
(9)  Vend without the insurance coverage specified; 
(10)  Vend from a stand on the sidewalk so as to block the sidewalk, or so as to block the entranceway to any building, nor shall a permit be issued for such activity under any circumstances. Also, no vending shall be permitted to block any driveway, crosswalk or bus stop; 
(11)  Allow the stand or any other item relating to the operation of the vending business to lean against or hang from any building or other structure lawfully placed on public property, without the owner's permission; or 
(12)  No vendor shall vend without securing and displaying written permission from the property owner and all business owners in the building, if any, adjoining the area of the vending. 
(Code 1998, § 74-34; Ord. No. 5087, § II, 2-4-2003) 
Sec. 70-31. - Cleanup responsibility. 
    A vendor shall keep his stand and vending area litter free. He must remove litter, caused by his products, off of any public or private property. A vendor with a pushcart shall have a trash container in or on the cart. 
(Code 1998, § 74-35; Ord. No. 5087, § II, 2-4-2003) 
Sec. 70-32. - Standards for stands. 
    A vendor's stand, or other device, shall be kept clean and in a safe condition when used on public property. 
(Code 1998, § 74-36; Ord. No. 5087, § II, 2-4-2003) 
Chapters 71-73 - RESERVED 
Chapter 74 - PLANNING[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

ARTICLE II. - REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Regional planning commission, T.C.A. § 13-3-101 et seq. 

Sec. 74-19. - Created. 
    There is created a regional planning commission. 
(Code 1981, § 19-16; Code 1998, § 78-26) 
State Law reference- Power of city to create planning commission, T.C.A. § 13-4-101. 
Sec. 74-20. - Membership. 
(a)  The regional planning commission shall consist of nine members. One of the nine members shall be a member of the board of mayor and aldermen, but in no event shall the mayor serve as a member of the planning commission. The remaining eight members shall be residents of the planning region of the city. The eight members who are residents of the planning region shall be called appointive members. The term of office of the member selected from the board of mayor and aldermen shall run concurrently with that member's term as alderman on the board of mayor and aldermen. The appointive members shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to the approval of the board of mayor and aldermen. All appointive members shall be appointed for terms of four years. 
(b)  The mayor may remove a member of the regional planning commission for cause specified in writing, served on the member, and after a hearing before the board of mayor and aldermen. The member against whom the charges are being brought shall be given not less than 15 days' written notice of the hearing. The removal of the member must be approved by a majority of the board of mayor and aldermen. Any vacancy in any appointive membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the appointment of a qualified person by the mayor, subject to the approval of the board of mayor and aldermen. 
(c)  All members of the planning commission shall serve without compensation as such. 
(Code 1981, § 19-17; Code 1998, § 78-27) 
State Law reference- Composition of planning commission, T.C.A. § 13-4-101. 
Sec. 74-21. - Election, term of chairperson. 
    The regional planning commission shall elect its chairperson from its appointive members. The term of office of the chairperson shall be for one year, with eligibility for reelection. 
(Code 1981, § 19-18; Code 1998, § 78-28) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, T.C.A. § 13-4-102. 
Sec. 74-22. - Records of findings and determinations. 
    The regional planning commission shall record its findings and determinations, the record of which shall be public records. 
(Code 1981, § 19-19; Code 1998, § 78-29) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, T.C.A. § 13-4-102. 
Sec. 74-23. - Rules for procedure and business. 
    The regional planning commission shall adopt rules for its procedure and transaction of business. 
(Code 1981, § 19-20; Code 1998, § 78-30) 
Sec. 74-24. - Statutory powers, duties and responsibilities. 
    The regional planning commission shall have the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in T.C.A. §§ 13-3-101-13-3-105, 13-3-201-13-3-203, 13-3-301-13-3-303, 13-3-401-13-3-411, 13-4-101-13-4-105, 13-4-301-13-4-309 and 13-7-201-13-7-210. The commission shall have, upon and after approval by the board of mayor and aldermen, the powers, duties and responsibilities as may be set forth in all acts relative to municipal and regional planning commissions. 
(Code 1981, § 19-21; Code 1998, § 78-31)

Chapter 78 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Pawnbrokers Act of 1988, T.C.A. § 45-6-201 et seq.; authority for municipal regulation of pawnbrokers, T.C.A. § 45-6-219; Junkyard Control Act of 1967, T.C.A. § 54-20-101 et seq.; power of municipality to regulate junkyards, T.C.A. § 54-20-113; scrap metal dealers, T.C.A. § 62-9-101 et seq.; flea market sales, T.C.A. § 47-25-1601 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 78-1-78-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AUTOMOBILE JUNKYARDS AND GRAVEYARDS 

Sec. 78-19. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Automobile graveyard means any lot or place which is exposed to the weather and upon which five or more inoperable motor vehicles of any type are stored, placed, dismantled, located or found. 
    Automobile junkyard means any lot or place within the city which is exposed to the weather and where five or more inoperable motor vehicles of any type are stored, placed or located for: 
(1)  The purpose of disassembly; 
(2)  The salvage of parts; 
(3)  Storage until crushed or recycled; or 
(4)  Any other purpose. 
    Inoperable motor vehicle means any motor vehicle, at the time a summons is issued for violation of this article, that: 
(1)  Has major or essential mechanical or body parts missing; 
(2)  Is wrecked, junked or partially disassembled; 
(3)  Is burned throughout; 
(4)  Cannot be started and driven legally upon the public streets or highways; 
(5)  Does not have a current registration plate from the state displayed lawfully on the vehicle; 
(6)  Is economically impractical to restore to operating condition; 
(7)  Meets any two or more of the following criteria: 
a.  Has one or more tires not inflated; 
b.  Has more than one broken window; 
c.  Has any visibly rusted areas; or 
d.  Has not been moved within six months; or 
(8)  Is defined in any code adopted by reference, including the International Property Maintenance Code. 
    Motor vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, excepting devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(b)  The terms "automobile graveyard" and "automobile junkyard" shall be construed to include an establishment having a current business license for that use and facilities for processing ferrous or nonferrous scrap metal and whose principal produce is scrap metal for sale; to any business holding a valid business license for that purpose and primarily devoted to the impoundment, storage, disassembly, salvage or demolition of motor vehicles. A motor vehicle dealer or vehicle repair operation holding a valid business license for that purpose and actively engaged in such business shall not be construed to constitute an automobile junkyard or automobile graveyard. 
(Code 1998, § 82-26; Ord. No. 4224, § II(16-80), (16-82), 6-4-1996) 
Sec. 78-20. - Location. 
    Automobile graveyards and automobile junkyards shall not be located in any zone of the city, except zones approved for industrial or manufacturing use. 
(Code 1998, § 82-27; Ord. No. 4224, § II(16-82), 6-4-1996) 
Sec. 78-21. - Storage of inoperable motor vehicles prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or allow to be maintained, on any lot or parcel, five or more inoperable motor vehicles or parts of automobiles, unless such lot or parcel is the site of a duly licensed business in an industrial or manufacturing zone. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to a motor vehicle dealer or repair operation holding a valid business license for that purpose and actively engaged in such business. 
(c)  This section shall not replace or supersede the housing code, as adopted by reference in section 22-96, or any other part of this Code, but shall be supplemental thereto. 
(Code 1998, § 82-28; Ord. No. 4224, § II(16-81), 6-4-1996) 
Sec. 78-22. - Manner of storing vehicles. 
    Every business holding a valid license to keep, store, repair, disassemble or salvage motor vehicles shall store such motor vehicles in such manner that they will not catch and hold water in which mosquitoes may breed or that will constitute a breeding place or habitat for rats, mice or other vermin. 
(Code 1998, § 82-29; Ord. No. 4224, § II(16-83), 6-4-1996) 
Sec. 78-23. - Fencing. 
    Every business licensed as an automobile graveyard or an automobile junkyard shall be enclosed by a closefitting opaque fence or appropriate structure touching the ground at the bottom. The fence or structure shall be not less than six feet in height. A fence is not required when, due to the lay of land, the contents of the yard are not visible from any public highway or street. 
(Code 1998, § 82-30; Ord. No. 4224, § II(16-84), 6-4-1996) 
Chapters 79-81 - RESERVED 
Chapter 82 - SIGNS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Compliance with laws and ordinances required. 
    All signs erected, placed or maintained shall comply with all applicable state and federal laws and all ordinances of the city, including but not limited to the building code, the electrical code, the gas code, the mechanical code, the plumbing code and chapter 114. 
(Code 1981, § 23-1; Code 1998, § 86-1) 
Sec. 82-2. - Inspection fees. 
(a)  In order to defray the cost and expense incurred by the city in making inspection of the signs and billboards in this chapter, there is imposed and levied an annual inspection fee as determined by the board of mayor and aldermen. The owner of the sign or billboard shall pay the fee into the office of the city treasurer. 
(b)  The fee shall be due and payable on all such signs on January 1. On all such signs erected, operated or maintained, the inspection fee shall be paid by the owner into the office of the city treasurer at the time of issuance of a permit therefor, and the fee shall again be due and payable on January 1 each year thereafter. 
(Code 1981, § 23-6; Code 1998, § 86-2) 
Sec. 82-3. - Distance from street or intersection. 
    No commercial ground sign or roof sign, signboard or billboard shall, for commercial advertising purposes, be placed, erected, constructed and maintained closer than 20 feet from the nearest street or street intersection. 
(Code 1981, § 23-2; Code 1998, § 86-3) 
Sec. 82-4. - Location in residential districts. 
    All commercial ground signs, roof signs, signboards and billboards erected in an undeveloped residential area zoned for residential purposes, which may be developed by the erection and construction of residence buildings near or in close proximity to such signs, rendering such signs dangerous or causing the sign to obstruct the view of or from the property, or which in any way interferes with the enjoyment of such property shall, upon written request of the city, within 90 days, be torn down and removed, after the passage of a resolution ordering its removal by the board of mayor and aldermen. A written notice of the request served either upon the owner of such sign, the lessee or the owner of the property upon which such sign is located shall be sufficient notice to the owner to make him liable for removal thereof under this section. 
(Code 1981, § 23-5; Code 1998, § 86-4) 
Secs. 82-5-82-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMIT 

Sec. 82-27. - Compliance as prerequisite to issuance. 
    No permit shall be issued pursuant to this article unless the sign or structure for which it is issued is in compliance or will be in compliance with all applicable state and federal laws and all ordinances of the city, including but not limited to the building code, the electrical code, the gas code, the mechanical code, the plumbing code and chapter 114. 
(Code 1981, § 23-18; Code 1998, § 86-31) 
Chapters 83-85 - RESERVED 
Chapter 86 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Tennessee Solid Waste Disposal Act, T.C.A. § 68-211-101 et seq.; county garbage and rubbish collection and disposal services, T.C.A. § 5-19-101 et seq.; municipal solid waste collections and disposal centers, T.C.A. § 68-211-851 et seq.; solid waste disposal fees, T.C.A. § 68-211-835; litter, T.C.A. § 39-14-502 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 86-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ashes means residue resulting from the combustion of coal, coke or wood in domestic or commercial stoves, furnaces or boilers. 
    Automated residential container means a 38- or 95-gallon universal roll-out cart supplied by and owned by the city and all replacements and weighing not over 250 pounds. 
    Construction refuse means all refuse, rubbish, wood, metal, plaster, rocks, earth, stone, pieces of masonry or concrete, etc., resulting from construction, alteration, demolition or excavation operations. 
    Director means the director of public works of the city or designee. 
    Furniture and appliances includes, but is not limited to: 
(1)  White goods (household appliances); 
(2)  Large furniture such as sofas, couches, dressers, bureaus, console televisions, mattresses, bed springs or other items of similar size or weight; or 
(3)  Carpeting of such volume that will not readily go in a compactor truck. 
    Hazardous solid waste includes, but is not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Lead acid storage batteries; 
(2)  Whole unshredded tires; 
(3)  Used oil as defined by T.C.A. § 68-211-1002(8); 
(4)  Radioactive waste; 
(5)  Infectious waste; and 
(6)  Any hazardous waste as defined by T.C.A. § 68-212-104. 
    Industrial waste means waste products of any manufacturing plant or process. 
    Nonautomated residential container means a water tight metal or plastic container with handles, having a tightfitting cover, weighing not over 75 pounds when full, and having a capacity not exceeding 32 gallons. 
    Nonresidential producer means all producers except residential and industrial producers. The term nonresidential producer includes, but is not limited to, any mobile home in a mobile home park as defined in section 62-1 and apartments. 
    Permittee means the holder of a valid solid waste collection permit or any employee or representative thereof. 
    Plastic bag means a bag made of plastic approximately two feet in diameter and four feet in length and of sufficient strength to contain the weight of the contents without breaking open. Plastic bags must be securely tied and shall contain only leaves and yard trimmings, except when used as liners for residential containers. 
    Producer means either the person responsible for the solid waste or the occupant of the place or building where such is produced or in which the person responsible for such has a place of business or residence. 
    Recyclable materials means materials that can be separated from other solid waste and recycled, including but not limited to newsprint, aluminum and other types of cans, glass bottles, used oil and plastic bottles of approved types. 
    Refuse container includes automated residential containers, nonautomated residential containers, special commercial containers, and standard commercial containers. 
    Residence means a room or rooms connected together, constituting a separate, independent housekeeping establishment, and physically separated from any other rooms or dwelling units in the same building and containing independent cooking, sleeping and sanitary facilities. 
    Residential producer means any structure containing two or fewer residential living units and occupied by not more than two individual families. The term residential producer does not include any mobile home in a mobile home park as defined in section 62-1. 
    Residential yard waste means vegetative matter such as branches, brush, grass, weeds or other cut foliage, resulting from gardening, general lawn maintenance and beautification of residential property, but excluding trees, large branches or stumps, and waste generated by land clearing operations, mining, agricultural and forestry operations. 
    Solid waste means all kitchen refuse, whether animal or vegetable; organic waste matter; decaying or discarded foodstuffs, both animal and vegetable; metal cans; refuse resulting from transportation, handling or preparation of food; crates; barrels; dead fowl or animals; all other decaying or decomposing substances including animal feces; cans, rags, glass, crockery and all other items which are commonly disposed of in waste receptacles; combustible trash, including but not limited to paper, cartons, boxes, magazines and excelsior; and noncombustible trash, including but not limited to metal, articles of clothing and other vegetable or mineral and similar waste products suitable for deposit in a refuse container as specified in this chapter. Any trash, garbage, refuse, yard waste, including recyclable materials when they become discarded, or sludge from a waste treatment plant, water supply treatment plant or air pollution control facility and any other discarded material, including solid, liquid, semisolid or contained gaseous material resulting from industrial, commercial and agricultural operations, and from community activities, but does not include solid or dissolved material in domestic sewage or solid or dissolved material in irrigation return flows or industrial discharges which are point sources subject to permits under section 402 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 USC 1342 et seq.), as amended, or source, special nuclear or byproduct materials as defined by the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 (42 USC 2011 et seq.). 
    Solid waste service means the complete removal, transportation and disposal of solid waste from any residence, business or other establishment. 
    Special commercial container means a roll-off or compactor-type container constructed for solid waste which must be transported to a sanitary landfill for service. 
    Standard commercial container means a dumpster-type container having a capacity of two or more cubic yards which is serviced at the location of use and which is constructed so that it can be handled by the equipment used for collection, as well as being watertight, having a tightfitting cover or closure, and that is verminproof. 
    Subscriber means any person, business or industry that elects to contract with a permitted solid waste collection firm for collection, transportation and disposal of solid waste. 
(Code 1998, § 90-1; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-1), 3-7-1995; Ord. No. 5434, § I, 8-1-2006; Ord. No. 6231, §§ II, III, 7-5-2016) 
Sec. 86-2. - Prohibited practices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than an owner or occupant, to: 
(1)  Place or deposit any item or material in any privately owned, operated or placed refuse container or otherwise on the property of any other person without permission. This subsection shall not be construed to prohibit the use of public refuse containers for their intended purpose. 
(2)  Uncover, turn over, move, remove, carry away, deface, mutilate, destroy, damage or interfere with any refuse container or rifle, pilfer, dig into or in any other manner disturb, upset, scatter or tamper with its contents. 
(3)  Appropriate, seize, extract or remove any solid waste from any residential, commercial or industrial container located upon private property or public right-of-way without the express consent of the owner or lessee of the container. 
(Code 1998, § 90-3; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-7), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-3. - Depositing in public places. 
    It shall be a violation for any person to throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place including, but not limited to, drive-in eating establishments, mall parking areas or any other business premises, other than in public or private receptacles for collection. 
(Code 1998, § 90-8; Ord. No. 4620, § I, 12-15-1998) 
Sec. 86-4. - Placement in receptacles to prevent scattering. 
(a)  It shall be a violation for any person to place litter in refuse containers in such a manner as to allow such material to fall to the ground, or over-flow the container, allowing the litter to be carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, other public place, or upon private property. Refuse containers shall be made secure from overturning and scattering of the contents by dogs or other animals. Any waste placed outside the refuse container will not be collected by the city. 
(b)  The owner, lessor or user of refuse containers shall be responsible for maintaining any such receptacle in conformance with this section. 
(c)  For the purpose of this section, the term "litter" means putrescible animal and vegetable waste resulting from transporting, handling, preparation, cooking or consumption of food, garbage, refuse, rubbish and all other waste material. 
(Code 1998, § 90-9; Ord. No. 4620, § I, 12-15-1998; Ord. No. 5434, § II, 8-1-2006) 
Sec. 86-5. - Demolition landfill fees; additional fee for tire disposal. 
    The board of mayor and aldermen may, by resolution, establish fees for use of the demolition landfill from time to time. A separate fee for the disposal of tires shall be established from time to time by resolution of the board of mayor and aldermen. 
(Code 1998, § 90-2; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-2), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-6. - Fees. 
    The board of mayor and aldermen may from time to time establish by resolution all garbage, trash services, landfill fees and any permit fees applicable to any activity under the provisions of this chapter of the Code. 
(Ord.No. 6589, § I, 7-5-2016) 
Secs. 86-7-86-28. - Reserved. 
Sec. 86-29. - By city. 
(a)  Solid waste to be collected by the city shall be placed by the producer in automated residential containers, which shall be covered at all times except when being emptied or filled. Such containers shall be furnished and kept in good repair by the producer. The producer shall have a sufficient number of automated residential containers to hold one week's accumulation of solid waste, but not to exceed four automated residential containers per residence or business. 
(b)  Collection shall be made once each week from the curbside or alley or at such other place as the director may designate, except as provided in subsection (e) of this section. 
(c)  The producer shall place automated residential containers and recycling containers adjacent to the alley or curbside facing the street properly and in the location designated by the director or designee no sooner than 24 hours before scheduled pickup. The producer shall remove all automated residential containers and recycling containers from the alley or curbside within 24 hours after the day of collection. Service will not be provided if the automated residential containers are not placed at the proper location at the time of collection. 
(d)  Except as provided in subsection (e) of this section, all solid waste, whether household waste, yard waste or other types of waste, shall only be placed for collection at or near a public street or alley that is improved by means of asphalt or concrete paving or by spreading of gravel of sufficient width and depth to provide support for the type of vehicle utilized to make such collections. The sufficiency of such street or alley improvements shall be determined by the director, giving consideration to the weight of the service vehicle, the area needed to maneuver and turn such vehicle and any other matter that would affect safety or efficiency of waste collection operations. 
(e)  The city may provide residential producers with weekly back yard pickup of solid waste, excluding yard waste. Residential producers receiving this service shall comply with any additional regulations issued by the director and shall pay a fee as set by the board of mayor and aldermen. 
(f)  Solid waste not placed as provided in this section shall be removed from the premises by the producer at his expense. Noncomplying containers will not be emptied by the city. 
(g)  The city shall not be responsible for damages to containers of insufficient strength or that crack from exposure to freezing temperatures or for damage not caused directly by the city. This subsection shall not constitute a waiver of any immunity for any cause. 
(h)  All solid waste covered by this section shall be placed adjacent to the alley or curbside in such a way as not to obstruct vehicular or pedestrian traffic or at such location as the director may designate. Waste not placed in accordance with this section shall be removed from the premises by the producer at his expense. 
(Code 1998, § 90-38; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-12), 3-7-1995; Ord. No. 5318, § I, 6-21-2005; Ord. No. 5434, § IV, 8-1-2006) 
Sec. 86-30. - Storage of solid waste and authorized containers. 
(a)  All solid waste to be collected by the city shall be placed in automated residential containers supplied by and owned by the city or replacements, except as set out in sections 86-34 through 86-41. One automated residential container will be assigned and delivered to each resident. If a producer wishes to purchase additional residential containers it can be done through the city and will be collected on the normal collection day for that resident. The cost of any additional automated residential container will be determined by the public works director. Automated residential containers, including replacements, assigned to individual residents remain the property of the city. Automated residential containers and all replacements removed from such residents will be considered stolen and appropriately processed through the applicable courts of law. 
(b)  All solid waste and solid waste refuse containers on property used as residential must be stored behind the front building line of the dwelling and shall not be stored in the front yard, as defined in section 114-1, or on front porches where they are clearly visible from any street. 
(c)  No owner or occupant of a property used as residential shall permit or allow solid waste or refuse containers to be stored in violation of this section. It shall be the duty and responsibility of every such owner or occupant to prevent the property from being utilized in such a manner. Both the owner and occupant of a property used as residential may be found in violation of this section for the failure of the occupant to store solid waste or refuse containers in compliance with this section. 
(Code 1998, § 90-36; Ord. No. 5392, § I, 4-18-2006; Ord. No. 5434, § III, 8-1-2006) 
Sec. 86-31. - Standard commercial containers. 
    All producers of solid waste using standard commercial containers or special commercial containers shall make arrangements with any permitted collector of solid waste on such terms and conditions as the parties may find mutually agreeable. 
(Code 1998, § 90-42; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-16), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-32. - Nonresidential producers. 
    All nonresidential solid waste producers not utilizing the types of containers set out in section 86-31 shall: 
(1)  Make arrangements with any permitted collector of solid waste on such terms and conditions as the parties may find mutually agreeable; or 
(2)  Pay a monthly fee, as established by the board of mayor and aldermen, for curbside collection of solid waste by the city, using automated residential containers. 
(Code 1998, § 90-43; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-17), 3-7-1995; Ord. No. 5434, § V, 8-1-2006) 
Sec. 86-33. - Solid waste brought into city. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bring any solid waste into the city that was generated by any person outside the city and place or deposit such waste for collection by municipal forces. This section shall not be construed to include solid waste that may be generated while traveling outside the city in a private passenger vehicle and carried to a residence and placed for collection. 
(Code 1998, § 90-7; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-8), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-34. - Recyclable waste. 
    Every resident is encouraged to separate recyclable material (newspapers, glass bottles, alumi- num and steel cans, used oil and plastic bottles of approved types) from all other solid waste and place such recyclable materials in approved containers supplied by the city. Recyclable materials shall not be placed in plastic bags. 
(Code 1998, § 90-37; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-11), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-35. - Residential yard waste. 
(a)  Residential yard waste shall be separated from other solid waste. Residential yard waste of suitable size may be placed in containers, as required for other solid waste, or placed in plastic bags or containers without lids or stacked adjacent to the alley or curbside in such a way as not to obstruct vehicular or pedestrian traffic or at such location as the director may designate. 
(b)  Residential yard waste will be removed from each residence once every other week by the city. 
(c)  Residential yard waste not placed in accordance with this section shall be removed from the premises by the producer at his expense. 
(Code 1998, § 90-39; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-13), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-36. - Brush, stumps, trees, limbs and leaves. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, tree stumps, trunks, limbs and roots resulting from normal maintenance and care or for the purpose of beautification of residential property by the resident will be removed by the city, provided the following conditions are met: 
(1)  None of the work of cutting, trimming or removal of the material was performed by a business or contractor; 
(2)  All stumps, trunks, limbs and roots are cut into lengths not longer than six feet; 
(3)  Each piece shall not exceed 50 pounds in weight; and 
(4)  All material is placed on the resident's property adjacent to the alley or curbside, provided that no such material shall block or obstruct a street, alley or sidewalk. 
(b)  Tree stumps, trunks, limbs, roots or other debris resulting from the removal of trees or other vegetation (i.e., landscaping or grading by a contractor, clearing or grubbing prior to construction of residential, commercial or other structures) shall be removed by and at the expense of the contractor, developer or owner to an area designated by the director. It shall be unlawful to place and leave any such material on any sidewalk or public right-of-way. 
(c)  The city shall not collect or remove a volume of tree stumps, roots, trees, large limbs or other types of vegetation exceeding two truck loads (approximately 40 cubic yards) in any two-week period. 
(d)  Leaves that are raked into piles or windrows at the curbside will be removed by the city between October 15 and January 15. Prior to and after these dates, leaves will be removed by the city only if placed at curbside in plastic bags or other suitable containers. 
(Code 1998, § 90-40; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-14), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-37. - Furniture, appliances and other household items. 
(a)  Furniture and appliances will be collected and removed from residences by the city on an on-call basis. The producer shall call the public works department to request that such items be picked up. However, the city shall not accept any refrigerator or freezer unless the door has been removed from such appliance. Furniture and appliances shall be placed on the producer's property adjacent to an alley or at the curbside. This section applies only to residences. Nonresidential producers shall be responsible for disposing of such items at their own expense. 
(b)  The board of mayor and aldermen shall establish a fee for the collection of the various items authorized by this section. All applicable fees shall be billed monthly by the city, and the account shall be due and payable within 30 days thereafter. 
(c)  All solid waste covered by this section shall be placed adjacent to the alley or curbside in such a way as not to obstruct vehicular or pedestrian traffic or at such location as the director may designate. Waste not placed in accordance with this section shall be removed from the premises by the producer at his expense. 
(Code 1998, § 90-41; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-15), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-38. - Hazardous materials. 
    The city may refuse to collect or transport solid waste containing any hazardous material or substance or any other material or substance that is declared to be prohibited from deposit in a solid waste landfill by any federal, state or local law or regulation. 
(Code 1998, § 90-44; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-6), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-40. - Industrial waste. 
    The removal and disposal of industrial waste shall be the responsibility of the producer. 
(Code 1998, § 90-5; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-4), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-41. - Construction waste. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of the contractor or owner to provide receptacles for loose debris, construction refuse, paper, building materials, scrap wood, metal or masonry and any other trash produced at the site. The site shall be kept litter-free, and waste shall be promptly removed by the producer at his expense and taken for disposal to an area designated by the director. 
(b)  The city may collect and remove waste material, as set out in subsection (a) of this section, on an on-call basis upon payment of a fee as may be established from time to time by the board of mayor and aldermen. Any such collection or removal shall be at the sole discretion of the director based upon: 
(1)  Disposition requirements of the waste material; 
(2)  The volume, weight, composition and location of the waste material; and 
(3)  Safety considerations for the employees involved in such collection and disposition. 
(Code 1998, § 90-6; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-5), 3-7-1995) 
Secs. 86-42-86-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONTRACT COLLECTORS AND HAULERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-71. - Enforcement. 
    The administration and enforcement of this article shall be the responsibility of the director. The permittee shall furnish the director with reasonable opportunity to ascertain whether or not service is performed in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1998, § 90-71; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-32), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-72. - Permitted activities. 
    A holder of a solid waste collection permit issued pursuant to this article may offer to make available to any nonresidential subscriber within the city a complete solid waste collection and transportation service at rates which shall be competitive with others rendering similar service. The permittee shall not be the exclusive provider of solid waste collection and transportation services in the city, and the city may license others to render such services or carry out such services at its discretion. The permittee shall be authorized to make agreements with and perform additional services for subscribers within the city, such as washing and cleaning containers, repairing containers or renting containers. 
(Code 1998, § 90-73; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-30), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-73. - Rules of operation. 
(a)  A person issued a permit pursuant to division 2 of this article shall provide all labor, equipment, tools, maintenance and all other expenses relative to the operation of the solid waste collection and transportation service. 
(b)  All solid waste, upon being removed from the premises where produced or accumulated, shall become the property of the permittee until disposed of in a lawful manner. 
(c)  All solid waste collected by the permittee shall be disposed of by the permittee. Nonrecyclable solid waste shall be disposed of at an approved solid waste disposal facility which meets all applicable state requirements. Any recyclable materials collected by the permittee shall be transported to a processing center or market at the permittee's sole expense. 
(d)  Solid waste containers shall not be placed in or upon public rights-of-way without the express written consent of the director. 
(e)  Collection and removal of solid waste shall be made without disrupting or halting vehicular traffic. 
(f)  The permittee shall not pick or sort solid waste while in the process of collection. If any spillage occurs during the transfer, the permittee shall clean the area immediately. The permittee shall replace all containers to their proper place prior to departing from the site. 
(g)  Before moving loaded special containers, the permittee shall tightly close and latch lids and doors to eliminate spillage. The loaded units shall be completely emptied of all refuse and returned to the location from which they were removed. 
(h)  All solid waste containers shall be furnished by the producer; however, this shall not prohibit the permittee from reaching a mutually satisfactory agreement with the producer to provide containers of any type. 
(i)  The permittee shall designate in writing the person to serve as agent of the permittee and liaison between the permittee and the city. 
(j)  The permittee shall notify subscribers if for any reason the permittee will not be able to remove and dispose of solid waste on the scheduled collection day. The permittee shall give as much advance notice as possible and shall specify the reason for the nonperformance. The permittee shall confirm the nonperformance and the reason for it in writing within 24 hours after the nonperformance. 
(k)  The permittee shall have established a city business address and shall maintain local or toll free telephone facilities for the receipt of subscribers' complaints Monday through Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. The permittee shall handle complaints in a courteous manner, and material missed in the regular collection shall be picked up within 24 hours after the complaint is received or after the material is missed. Any complaints made to the city by subscribers shall be forwarded to the permittee. 
(l)  The permittee shall furnish quarterly reports to the director on the collection services performed by the permittee under a permit, showing the total number of cubic yards and tons of waste hauled the preceding three months. 
(m)  A record of all complaints by subscribers shall be maintained by the permittee for a period of two years from the date of the complaint, and such records shall be made available to the director for his inspection upon request during normal business hours. 
(Code 1998, § 90-74; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-31), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-74. - Equipment. 
(a)  All trucks and other mobile equipment used by a person issued a permit under division 2 of this article in the performance of services shall be equipped with all safety equipment required by federal or state laws or regulations and shall be maintained in a clean, safe and sanitary condition. The name of the permittee shall be prominently displayed. The permittee shall not use a firm name containing the term "city" or other words implying municipal ownership. 
(b)  Every truck and every other piece of equipment for collecting or hauling solid waste shall have a tightly closed body to keep to a minimum the nuisance of odors and shall be watertight to prevent spillage of wet residue from the truck or other equipment onto the streets, roads or grounds. Only truck bodies specifically constructed by a recognized manufacturer of this type of specialized equipment for handling solid waste is acceptable. Sufficient collection equipment shall be maintained and used by the permittee to provide adequate service to all subscribers of the permittee. 
(c)  The permittee shall be responsible for maintaining equipment in a manner so as to ensure satisfactory performance to all his subscribers. Failure to do so will be sufficient cause for termination of this permit. 
(d)  The permittee shall provide and maintain radio or mobile telephone communication with all vehicles used in the collection and transportation of solid waste. 
(Code 1998, § 90-75; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-26), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-75. - Employees of permittee. 
(a)  Under this article, the permittee's employees shall wear clean, appropriate clothing. Use of loud, abusive, indecent or profane language by employees; traffic violations; failure to clean up spillage; or willful damage to containers by employees may be sufficient cause for termination of a permit. 
(b)  Each of the permittee's employees shall, at all times, have and shall carry a valid state operator's license for the type of vehicle he is operating. 
(Code 1998, § 90-76; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-28), 3-7-1995) 
Secs. 86-76-86-93. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 86-94. - Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to collect, haul or remove solid waste from any place of business or profession or from any residential establishment within the city without a valid solid waste collection permit issued by the city. 
(b)  A permit issued pursuant to this division shall not be exclusive, and the city reserves the right to issue any number of solid waste collection permits to any person, upon meeting the requirements of this article. 
(c)  Industrial facilities that remove and dispose of waste generated by such industry are excluded from this section. 
(d)  The city retains and reserves the right to collect, haul, remove or dispose of solid waste or recyclable material from any place of business or profession or from any residential establishment within the city at any time, without complying with the permit requirements established in this article. 
(e)  The city reserves the exclusive right to provide solid waste collection and transportation to all residential producers. 
(Code 1998, § 90-101; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-20), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-95. - Application; investigation. 
(a)  Every applicant for a solid waste collection permit shall submit the following: 
(1)  The full name, business address and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  An affidavit of noncollusion in a form approved by the city attorney. 
(3)  Evidence of the applicant's ability to perform the service, which shall be comprised of the following: proof that the applicant owns, leases or controls vehicles of the type required in this article. If the applicant is not the actual owner or lessee of the equipment, the certificate shall state the source from which the equipment will be obtained and shall be accompanied by a certificate from the owner or person in control of the equipment definitely granting to the applicant the control of the equipment during the term of the permit. 
(4)  Satisfactory evidence that the applicant has available a disposal site meeting the laws of the state and other regulatory authorities. 
(5)  Such other information deemed relevant by the director. 
(b)  The director shall make such investigation as he deems necessary to determine the ability of the applicant to perform the service, and the director reserves the right to reject any application if the investigation fails to satisfy him that the applicant is properly qualified to carry out the obligations of the permit. 
(Code 1998, § 90-102; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-22), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-96. - Fee. 
    An annual fee, as established by resolution of the board of mayor and aldermen, shall be paid to the city for each solid waste collection permit. 
(Code 1998, § 90-103; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-24), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-97. - Insurance. 
    A person issued a permit pursuant to division 2 of this article shall maintain workers' compensation general liability, automobile public liability and property damage insurance as provided by law with a company authorized to do business in the state. The director may demand proof that coverage is in effect at any time during the term of a solid waste collection permit. All insurance premiums shall be paid by the permittee. 
(Code 1998, § 90-72; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-27), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-98. - Duration. 
    Solid waste collection permits shall be issued by the director for a period of one year. 
(Code 1998, § 90-104; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-23), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-99. - Limitations. 
(a)  A permit for collection and transportation of solid waste shall not constitute a franchise, nor shall it be deemed or construed as such. 
(b)  The permittee shall, at his own expense, comply with all applicable federal, state or local laws, rules and regulations, including but not limited to those governing the inspection and licensing of equipment used in the performance of services authorized by the permit. 
(c)  The issuance of a solid waste collection permit shall not be construed in any way to restrict or limit the legislative discretion of the city to amend or repeal any applicable sections of this Code or to amend or repeal any rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to it or to enact a rate regulation ordinance. 
(d)  The permittee shall not sell, assign, sublet or transfer a permit or any interest thereof, nor shall he subpermit any portion of the service to be performed under a permit. Any attempt to sell, transfer, assign or subpermit shall be void and is sufficient cause to terminate the permit. 
(e)  After adjudication of bankruptcy either by voluntary or involuntary proceedings, the permit shall immediately terminate, and in no event shall the permit be treated as an asset of the permittee. 
(f)  A permit issued pursuant to this article shall not be construed as a property right, but shall be deemed a privilege. 
(Code 1998, § 90-105; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-25), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-100. - Renewal. 
(a)  Not less than 60 days prior to the expiration of a permit issued pursuant to this division, a permittee desiring to renew the permit shall make written application to the director. 
(b)  Upon receipt of such request, the director shall cause to be published in the largest newspaper of general circulation within the city a notice of the request for renewal. 
(c)  The director shall, for a period of 30 days, receive comments or complaints from any citizen, subscriber or solid waste producer in the city regarding service provided by the applicant. 
(d)  The director shall review all comments and complaints received and the record of service provided by the permittee during the preceding year, giving consideration to the following: 
(1)  The number of substantiated complaints received by the city; 
(2)  How satisfactorily such complaints were resolved; 
(3)  The general performance of the permittee; 
(4)  Whether the permittee is incurring outstanding debts for wages or other obligations to the extent that performance of service is hindered; 
(5)  Violation of city ordinances or state or federal law; 
(6)  Assignment, transferring or subpermitting any interest under a permit; 
(7)  Failure to maintain insurance as prescribed in this article; and 
(8)  Such other information as may be deemed appropriate by the director. 
(e)  If the director finds the permittee's performance unsatisfactory, the permit shall not be renewed. The director shall provide a written report to the board of mayor and aldermen of his findings and shall send a notice of his determination to the permittee by certified mail. Such notice to the permittee shall include a requirement that he cease all operations within the city within 90 days. 
(Code 1998, § 90-106; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-29), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-101. - Revocation. 
(a)  Upon a finding by the director that any person issued a permit pursuant to this division has failed and continues to fail to substantially comply with all applicable terms of this article, he shall notify the permittee by certified mail that a show cause hearing will be held by the director within 20 days after receipt of the notice. 
(b)  The permittee shall have the opportunity at such hearing to show cause why his solid waste permit should not be revoked, may offer evidence and may be represented by counsel. 
(c)  Revocation of a solid waste collection permit may be reviewed pursuant to T.C.A. § 27-9-101 et seq. 
(Code 1998, § 90-107; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-33), 3-7-1995) 
Sec. 86-102. - Termination. 
    The city may, at its sole and unfettered discretion, terminate all permitted solid waste collections for any reason, upon the giving of 90 days' advance written notice to all holders of valid permits. 
(Code 1998, § 90-108; Ord. No. 4012, § II(9-21), 3-7-1995) 
Chapters 87-89 - RESERVED 
Chapter 90 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Streets and other public improvements generally, T.C.A. § 7-31-101 et seq.; authority to construct, improve streets, sidewalks, public ways, assess costs therefor, T.C.A. § 7-32-101 et seq.; authorization for sidewalk construction, T.C.A. § 7-31-105; duty of city to install ramps for disabled persons, T.C.A. § 7-31-114; prohibited sidewalk uses, T.C.A. § 7-31-1206; obstruction of roads and highways, T.C.A. § 39-17-307; tampering with construction signs and barricades prohibited, T.C.A. § 39-17-108; parades of state national guard have right-of-way in streets, T.C.A. § 58-1-601. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 90-1. - Coal holes, cellar doors or other holes. 
(a)  No cellar way, coal hole or other hole of like nature opening in or upon a public street or sidewalk shall be allowed to be or remain in a dangerous condition unless guarded by bars or otherwise. All coal holes or other means of access to buildings shall be provided with substantial locks. 
(b)  No person shall leave any coal hole or aperture opened or unfastened except while in use with workmen present or unless guarded by bars or otherwise. 
(c)  Every cellar door opening upon public pavement shall be of iron grating and so constructed that when shut it shall be on a level with the pavement and have its grating running at right angles to the line of the street. No cellar door shall be permitted to extend more than five feet from the wall of the building served by or be so constructed as to open downward. 
(d)  Whenever the owner or occupant of any premises upon which there is a cellar, hole, area or vault opening on the street or sidewalk is notified by the city authorities that the covering of such is insecure and dangerous, it shall be his duty to repair it at once. If he fails to do so after five days' notice, it shall be the duty of the city manager to have the covering repaired or placed in safe condition and collect the cost thereof from the owner or occupant. 
(Code 1981, § 24-7; Code 1998, § 94-6) 
Sec. 90-2. - Obstructing flow of water.
