    No person occupying the streets with his work or any appurtenances shall obstruct or impede the flow of water in any street, gutter, alley or drain. 
(Code 1981, § 24-8; Code 1998, § 94-7) 
Sec. 90-3. - Banners and placards. 
    No person shall place in, along or across any public street or other public property any banner or placard and there display the banner unless and until he shall have obtained a permit from the director of public works. 
(Code 1981, § 24-11; Code 1998, § 94-8) 
Sec. 90-4. - Gates or doors on property line. 
    Every gate or door built or constructed in any fence or wall standing upon the property line, except doors to public buildings which are required to be hung to open outward, shall be hung to open inward. This section shall not apply to screen doors closed by a spring. 
(Code 1981, § 24-13; Code 1998, § 94-10) 
Secs. 90-5-90-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREETS 

Sec. 90-27. - Naming responsibility of department of transportation. 
    The department of transportation shall place the names of the streets at all street intersections. 
(Code 1981, § 24-14; Code 1998, § 94-11) 
Sec. 90-28. - Acceptance required; exceptions; standards; monuments. 
(a)  Improvements. The city shall not accept, lay out, open, improve, grade, pave or light any street or lay or authorize water mains or sewers or connections to be laid in any street within the city, unless such street shall have been accepted or opened as or shall otherwise have received the legal status of a public street prior to the adoption of such plan or unless such street corresponds in its location and lines with a street shown on a subdivision plat approved by the planning commission or with a street plat made and adopted by the planning commission. However, the board of mayor and aldermen may locate and construct or may accept any other street, provided the ordinance or other measure for such location and construction or for such acceptance is first submitted to the planning commission for its approval and, if disapproved by the commission, is passed by a majority of the entire membership of the board of mayor and aldermen. A street, approved by the planning commission upon such submission or constructed or accepted by the majority vote after disapproval by the commission, shall have the status of an approved street as fully as though it had been originally shown on a subdivision plat approved by the planning commission or on a plat made and adopted by the planning commission. The right-of-way width of any major street so approved shall conform to the width designated on the officially adopted major street plan. The minimum right-of-way width for any minor street so approved shall be 50 feet; provided, however, that the planning commission shall have the authority to approve a right-of-way width of less than 50 feet if, because of topography or other special conditions, an undue hardship would be created by providing a greater width and if, after thorough study, the commission determines that the narrower width will not unduly restrict the flow of traffic or hinder the extension of services to the adjacent property. 
(b)  Standards. If any person shall lay out a new addition to the city or a new street, the addition or street shall be surveyed and opened in such manner as to conform to adjacent streets surveyed. 
(c)  Monuments. Before any addition or street is accepted by the city, the lines of such addition or street shall be clearly defined by substantial monuments constructed according to the following specifications: 
(1)  The top of each and every monument shall be set not more than six inches below the established grade of the curb, such monument to be set in the center of the street and at each angle or change of direction. 
(2)  The monument shall be of stone or concrete, two feet in depth and four inches square on top, the bottom to be larger than the top. 
(3)  The point on top shall be marked by a neat hole, one-fourth inch in diameter and one-half inch deep, or by a copper plug one-eighth inch by one inch, set in. 
(Code 1981, §§ 24-15, 24-16; Code 1998, § 94-12) 
Sec. 90-29. - Removing or damaging monuments, grades or line pegs. 
    No person shall remove, deface or destroy any monuments located as provided in this chapter or any grade or line pegs. 
(Code 1981, § 24-17; Code 1998, § 94-13) 
Secs. 90-30-90-46. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS AND FOOTWAYS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to construct, improve streets, sidewalks, public ways, assess costs therefor, T.C.A. § 7-32-101 et seq.; authorization for sidewalk construction, T.C.A. § 7-31-105; duty of city to install ramps for disabled persons, T.C.A. § 7-31-114; prohibited sidewalk uses, T.C.A. § 7-31-1206. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-47. - Sweeping sidewalks in front of business establishments. 
    Each person conducting business in a first-floor location having a paved sidewalk in front of his building shall have the sidewalk swept before opening his place of business each morning, except Sunday, and shall have the sidewalk swept at the time of closing his place of business each Saturday night. 
(Code 1981, § 24-1; Code 1998, § 94-1) 
Sec. 90-48. - Heavy substances on sidewalks, curb, gutter. 
    No hard substance of a greater weight than 400 pounds shall be handled upon a sidewalk, curb or gutter. 
(Code 1981, § 24-2; Code 1998, § 94-2) 
Sec. 90-49. - Removal of snow, ice, sleet, mud from sidewalks, footways. 
    It shall be the duty of the occupant of every house or lot which has a sidewalk or footway of brick, stone, concrete or other permanent material adjoining or touching upon the sidewalk or footway in the front, rear or either side to have all snow removed from such sidewalk or foot pavement within six hours after the snow shall have ceased falling, unless such snow shall have fallen during the night, in which case it shall be removed by 10:00 a.m. the next morning. The same requirements shall exist with respect to ice, sleet or mud on the sidewalks or footways, except that when it cannot be removed without injury to the sidewalk it shall be covered within a like period of time with sawdust, ashes or other material which would render it safe for travel. When there is no tenement on such lot or any occupant of any tenement thereon, it shall be the duty of the owner of such lot or tenement to have the snow removed or the ice, sleet or mud removed or covered as required in this section for occupants. 
(Code 1981, § 24-3; Code 1998, § 94-3) 
Sec. 90-50. - Roller skates on sidewalk. 
    No person shall ride on or use roller skates, roller blades, in-line roller skates or similar devices on any sidewalk within fire district No. 1 or upon the sidewalk abutting any four-lane street or highway. 
(Code 1981, § 24-5; Code 1998, § 94-4; Ord. No. 4223, § I, 6-4-1996) 
Secs. 90-51-90-73. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SIDEWALK DINING FACILITIES 
Sec. 90-74. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Downtown business area includes the property inside the area bounded on the south by Main Street, the west by Clinchfield Street, the north by Sullivan Street and the east by the intersection of Sullivan and Main Streets. 
    Sidewalk cafe dining facility means the placing, locating or permitting of the placing or locating of chairs and tables on the public right-of-way or property, such as sidewalks, adjacent to a street level business licensed to operate as an eating establishment where food and/or other refreshments are served. Sidewalk vendors shall not be permitted to establish a sidewalk cafe dining facility. A sidewalk cafe dining facility may provide waiter or waitress services or may be self-service. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(b)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-75. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person who maintains or operates any sidewalk cafe dining facility within any public right-of-way without first obtaining a permit from the city shall be deemed guilty of a offense and upon conviction thereof shall be fined $50.00 per day, and each day that such violation continues to occur shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(c)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-76. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose of this section is to promote the general economic development and atmosphere of the downtown business area for the general benefit of all businesses and citizens located there, and no rights of individuals or individual businesses are created in this section. No property right is created by this section. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(a)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-77. - Authorized in downtown business area. 
(a)  Sidewalk cafe dining facilities are authorized to be located within the public right-of-way in that area of downtown known as the downtown business area as hereinafter described, subject to the requirements contained herein. 
(b)  The permit holder shall set up the sidewalk cafe dining facility, including, but not limited to, the furniture, canopies, fencing or other accessories used for the sidewalk cafe dining facility, only in the area designated by the city on the permit, specifically excluding roadways. The sidewalk cafe dining facility shall not impede, endanger or interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(a), (e)(17)), 2-17-2009) 
Secs. 90-78-90-97. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Permits 

Sec. 90-98. - Required. 
(a)  Operation of a sidewalk cafe dining facility shall require a permit from the department of public works. Such permits shall be available only for locations in the downtown business area. 
(b)  Any person desiring to operate a sidewalk cafe dining facility shall file an application for a permit as required by the department of public works, pay to the city a nonrefundable application fee as established by resolution of the board of mayor and aldermen to cover the cost of processing such application. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(d), (e)(1)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-99. - Term and renewal. 
    All permits issued pursuant to this section shall be for a period of one year, renewable annually, and must be posted on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(2)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-100. - Property owner approval required; responsibility for damage to public right-of-way. 
    If an applicant is not the owner of the property abutting the affected right-of-way, such application must have written approval by the owner of said property. Both the applicant and the owner of the abutting property, if different from the applicant, are responsible for any damage to the public right-of-way arising out of operation of a sidewalk cafe dining facility, and must immediately restore the right-of-way upon request to the specifications of the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(2)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-101. - Nonrefundable application fee. 
    Each application must be accompanied by the application fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule, which shall be nonrefundable. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(3)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-102. - Time for application for renewal; nonrefundable renewal fee. 
    If a renewal is desired, application for renewal must be made at least 30 days prior to the expiration of the existing permit, and each renewal application must be accompanied by a fee established by the board of mayor and aldermen, which shall be nonrefundable. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(3)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-103. - Plan and area description required. 
(a)  Each application must be accompanied by a plan showing all proposed activities to be conducted upon the public right-of-way and all items proposed to be placed upon said right-of-way. Additionally, a description of the area proposed to be encumbered must accompany each application. 
(b)  The plan presented at the time application is sought must include every activity proposed to be conducted upon the public right-of-way. For example, if food service is planned for the sidewalk area, the application must so state. If any entertainment or music is contemplated, the application must disclose this in detail. Anything not specifically included in an application shall be considered to be excluded. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(4), (6)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-104. - Indemnification of city. 
    The applicant shall hold harmless and indemnify the city from any and all liability resulting from personal injury or property damage resulting in any way from the operation of sidewalk cafe facilities, including court costs and attorneys' fees. Proof of insurance in an amount of not less than $1,000,000.00 and in a form acceptable to the city from a company licensed to do business in this state must be furnished with the application. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(11)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-105. - Cancellation or suspension of permit. 
    Any permit issued pursuant to this section may be immediately canceled or suspended by the director of public works for any reason and at any time. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(20)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-106. - Permit not transferable. 
    The permit issued shall be personal to the permit holder only and shall not be transferable in any manner. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(20)), 2-17-2009) 
Secs. 90-107-90-125. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Rules and Regulations 

Sec. 90-126. - Fencing or other barrier required. 
    Each valid sidewalk cafe dining facility must be fenced or surrounded on all sides except for designated entrances and exits. The fencing or surrounding barrier must not be permanent or attached to the sidewalk but must consist of a barrier not less than 40 inches high and must be constructed of a substantial material without gaps or spaces that would allow ingress and egress of the premises except through designated entrances and exits. Examples of substantial materials would include but not be limited to securely connected planters, decorative fencing or other decorative architectural or landscaping materials. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(18)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-127. - Minimum sidewalk width, exception; obstruction of access to parked vehicles prohibited. 
(a)  A minimum of six feet in width of sidewalk or the minimum required by the Americans with Disabilities Act, whichever is wider, must be left clear at all times for pedestrian traffic (measured from the edge of the encroachment to the curb or to any other obstruction, such as planters, trees, signposts, etc.) and placement must not obstruct ingress or egress from vehicles parked at the curb. 
(b)  In areas of congested pedestrian activity, the director of public works is authorized to require a wider pedestrian path, as circumstances dictate. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(7)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-128. - Obstruction of sidewalk, crosswalk, bus stops, and building ingress and egress prohibited. 
    The area shall not block ingress or egress to or from any building. A sidewalk cafe dining facility must not obstruct any doorway. Also, no items shall be placed so as to block any driveway, crosswalk, or bus stop. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(7), (9)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-129. - Removal of items by city. 
(a)  The director of public works may require the permit holder, at the permit holder's expense, to temporarily remove items within the encroachment area when street, sidewalk, common area or utility repairs in the opinion of the director of public works necessitate such action. 
(b)  In addition, the city shall have the right, at any time and for any reason, with or without notice, to remove from the public right-of-way any and all items placed thereon pursuant to any permit issued under this section, and to dispose of same in any manner without liability to the permit holder or to any other party; provided, however, that the director of the department of public works shall use his best efforts to provide at least 24 hours' notice to any permit holder whose operations shall be affected by the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(14), (20)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-130. - Maintenance and cleanup. 
(a)  The sidewalk cafe dining location and the area surrounding the sidewalk cafe dining location must be kept completely free of debris, trash or litter of any type. Cleanup of all debris, trash or litter must occur on a periodic basis during the day, and again at the close of each business day. Such cleanup and maintenance shall be the joint responsibility of the applicant and the property owner, if different from the applicant. The permit holder shall provide proper containers or some other means for the collection of waste and trash within the sidewalk cafe dining location. All waste and trash shall be properly disposed of by the permit holder. 
(b)  Tables, chairs, umbrellas and any other objects provided shall be maintained with a clean and attractive appearance and shall be kept safe and in good repair at all times. 
(c)  The permit holder shall be responsible for the maintenance, upkeep and security of the furniture and accessories of the sidewalk cafe dining facility and the city shall not be responsible for the same. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(8), (10), (15)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-131. - Stakes, rods, support poles, holes and permanent fixtures in right-of-way prohibited. 
    No stakes, rods, support poles or holes for whatever purpose are allowed to be drilled in the public right-of-way. No permanent fixtures are permitted in the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(4)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-132. - Excessive noise prohibited. 
    The permit holder shall not allow sound or permit sound or the sounding of any device on the public property which produces a loud noise or use or operate any loudspeaker, public address system, radio, sound amplifier or similar device that causes annoyance to neighboring property. Additionally, the permit holder shall not have on the premises any bell, siren, horn, loudspeaker or any similar device to attract the attention of possible customers nor shall the permit holder use any such device to attract attention. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(5)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-133. - Sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
    The sale and consumption of beer or alcoholic beverages are permitted on the public right-of-way only in the sidewalk dining facility, and then only if the requirements of all pertinent laws, rules and regulations have been met, including obtaining the required permits. The business owner must post an informational sign conspicuously posted in the sidewalk cafe dining facility that properly advises patrons that it is illegal to consume beer or alcoholic beverages or have an open container of the same outside the sidewalk cafe dining facility. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(12)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-134. - Consumption of alcoholic beverages by employees prohibited. 
    Employees of the permit holder of the sidewalk cafe dining facility shall not consume alcoholic beverages while working in the sidewalk cafe dining facility. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(19)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-135. - Food preparation on public right-of-way prohibited. 
    Food preparation on the public right-of-way is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(13)), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-136. - Signs. 
    Other than the informational sign required in section 90-133 signs shall not be attached to the sidewalk cafe dining facility. 
(Ord. No. 5810, § I(94-14(e)(16)), 2-17-2009) 
Secs. 90-137-90-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to construct, improve streets, sidewalks, public ways, assess costs therefor, T.C.A. § 7-32-101 et seq. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 90-156. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Curbline means the inside edge of the top of a curb. 
    Principal structure means a structure in which is conducted the principal uses of the lot on which it is situated. In any residential or agricultural district, any dwelling shall be deemed the principal structure on the lot on which the same is situated. Carports and garages, if permanently attached to the principal structure, shall be deemed a part of the principal structure. Awnings, porches, patios, or similar attachments shall be deemed a part of the principal structure. 
    Principal use means the specific primary purpose for which land or a building is used or is intended to be used. 
    Roadway means the actual road surface including necessary road shoulders and drainage facilities, including ditches and curbs and gutters, which is used to transport motor vehicles. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of a street between the curblines, or if there are no curblines, the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines, intended for use by pedestrians. 
    Street means any public way or part thereof, including but not limited to a boulevard, avenue, highway, road, lane or alley. 
(b)  For the purpose of this division, when not inconsistent with the context, the term "structure" includes the term "building;" the term "lot" includes the term "plot" or "parcel;" and whenever a provision or section requires the head of a department or some other city official to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize the head of the department or other official to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or perform the duty, unless the terms of the provision or section specify otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 6006, § I(94-502), 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 90-157. - Purpose 
(a)  The board of mayor and aldermen finds and declares that the construction of sidewalks improves pedestrian safety; expands opportunities for recreational walking and running activities; provides more cohesive neighborhoods; that the National Cooperative Highway Research program determined that pedestrians are significantly less likely to be struck by car while walking on a sidewalk along a street; and that "A Policy on Geometric Design of Highways and Streets" by the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials notes that sidewalks are an essential part of city streets. 
(b)  The purpose of this division is to establish the general requirement to construct sidewalks along streets, and to provide a comprehensive system of sidewalks within the city to promote the health, safety, and welfare of the inhabitants of the city. 
(Ord. No. 6006, § I(94-501), 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 90-158. - Single-family houses and duplexes exempt from division 
    Improvement, renovation, or repair of a single-family house or duplex shall be exempt from the requirements of this division. 
(Ord. No. 6006, § I(94-503), 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 90-159. - Sidewalk board created; duties. 
(a)  There is created for the administration of this division the sidewalk board. The sidewalk board shall consist of six members. The city engineer, the director of planning, the director of community services and the director of transportation shall each be an ex officio member of the sidewalk board for whom a designee may act in their absence. The remaining members of the sidewalk board shall be a member of the public at large, appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the board of mayor and aldermen, who shall be appointed for a term of five years or until their respective successors are appointed and qualified. 
(b)  Members appointed to fill vacancies shall have the same general qualifications required for their predecessors. All appointed members shall be persons of good reputation having diverse interests and who have been actively identified with the development and improvement of the city. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the sidewalk board to plan, set priorities and determine areas of city sidewalks that require repair or replacement. The sidewalk board shall determine what areas may have designed sidewalks and what areas may have landscaping, and the sidewalk board shall prepare and keep up to date a citywide sidewalk plan. 
(Code 1981, § 24-71; Code 1998, § 94-156) 
Sec. 90-160. - Permit. 
    No person shall construct a sidewalk without a permit from the director of public works. 
(Code 1981, § 24-69; Code 1998, § 94-157) 
Sec. 90-161. - Contractor's bond prerequisite to permit. 
    No sidewalk construction permit shall be issued to any contractor who has not previously given bond to the city in an amount as determined by the board of mayor and aldermen, conditioned to indemnify the city against loss or damage for injury to person or property due to the prosecution of work under this division and to bind such contractor to comply with the terms of this chapter. 
(Code 1981, § 24-70; Code 1998, § 94-158) 
Sec. 90-162. - Authority to require construction or repair by abutting owner. 
    The board of mayor and aldermen, whenever it is deemed necessary for the public welfare, may require the owner of any lot or part of lot in the city fronting upon any public street to construct and keep in repair a good and substantial sidewalk or travel way along the whole street frontage of his lot, of a width and materials prescribed by resolution of the board. 
(Code 1981, § 24-65; Code 1998, § 94-159) 
Sec. 90-163. - Notice to owner to construct or repair. 
    When a person is instructed by resolution by the board of mayor and aldermen to construct or repair a sidewalk, the city recorder shall give such person written notice stating the action of the board and specifically setting forth the work to be done and the length of time within which the work shall be done, provided that the time fixed shall not be less than 60 days. 
(Code 1981, § 24-66; Code 1998, § 94-160) 
Sec. 90-164. - Effect of noncompliance with notice. 
    If the owner of a lot shall refuse to build or repair sidewalks or foot pavements within the time required by the notice required in this division and in accordance therewith, the board of mayor and aldermen, through the city manager, may contract for the construction or repair of the sidewalk and shall pay the cost thereof out of the street fund. The cost of such work shall, from the date work is begun, constitute a lien on the property, such lien to be equal in dignity to liens for the city property tax. Such lien may be enforced by attachments at law or in equity or in the manner provided in the Charter. The city attorney shall enforce the lien. 
(Code 1981, § 24-67; Code 1998, § 94-161) 
Sec. 90-165. - Suit for amounts paid as costs. 
    The amount paid by the city as provided in section 90-164 may be recovered against such owner by suit before any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1981, § 24-68; Code 1998, § 94-162) 
Secs. 90-166-90-183. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Subdivision Sidewalks 

Sec. 90-184. - General requirements. 
(a)  When sidewalks are not otherwise controlled by the subdivision regulations approved by the city regional planning commission (on file in the city clerk's office), sidewalks shall be constructed along the street frontage, except for limited access highway frontage (Interstate 81, Interstate 26 and John B. Dennis Highway), of all industrial, commercial, office, professional, semipublic and multifamily residential developments whenever a new principal structure is built or erected. 
(b)  The construction of required sidewalks shall be completed, or if applicable, a fee in lieu of construction paid before a certificate of occupancy shall be issued by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 6006, § I(94-504), 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 90-185. - Fee in lieu of construction. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided herein, when a sidewalk is required to be constructed, the city engineer may waive the requirement and permit the payment of a fee in lieu of construction after considering: 
(1)  Pedestrian safety, school locations, connection to existing sidewalks, and other engineering and community concerns; or 
(2)  When it would be in the best interest of the city that sidewalk construction be postponed due to pending street or utility construction. 
(b)  Applicants must make a written request to the city engineer for a waiver. If a waiver is granted, a fee will be assessed in lieu of constructing the sidewalk. The fee shall be based on the market price of the construction of the sidewalk plus five percent as determined by the city engineer. 
(c)  In the event a fee in lieu of constructing a sidewalk is approved, the property owner shall provide to the city in a form approved by the city attorney a recorded easement for street right-of-way, which may include future development of the sidewalk. 
(d)  Grading shall be done in preparation for future sidewalks or pedestrian pathways. 
(e)  The fee shall be paid in full before a certificate of occupancy is issued. Fees collected will go into a city fund dedicated to sidewalk and pedestrian pathway construction. Disbursal from such fund is not geographically constrained, and may be used to install sidewalks anywhere in the city. 
(f)  Such waiver and payment in lieu of construction is not permitted when one or more of the following circumstances exist: 
(1)  The location is specified for sidewalks in the city's adopted sidewalk plan; 
(2)  The location is within 1,000 feet (street distance) of an existing sidewalk on the same side of the street; 
(3)  The development is expected to generate significant numbers of pedestrians. Examples include, but are not limited to, schools, day care centers, office buildings, churches, multifamily residential buildings, and other residential facilities such as group homes, nursing homes and residential homes for the aged; 
(4)  The development contains retail uses expected to attract customers from residences, retail area, places of employment, or places of public assembly within 1,500 feet of the development; 
(5)  The development is within 1,500 feet (street distance) of a regular city transit stop; or 
(6)  The new development is within one-half mile (street distance) of an existing or proposed school. 
(Ord. No. 6006, § I(94-505), 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 90-186. - Design and construction standards. 
    Design and construction details of required sidewalks shall be included with the development or access site plan. The city engineer shall review and approve the plans prior to the issuance of a building permit by the building official. Except as otherwise provided in section 90-190 sidewalks shall be constructed in accordance with the general requirements and standards of sidewalk design in the city's design standards. The city engineer shall be responsible for inspection of sidewalks during construction. Completion of sidewalk construction shall be required to the satisfaction of the city engineer before a certificate of occupancy will be issued. 
(Ord. No. 6006, § I(94-506), 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 90-187. - Insufficient right-of-way. 
    When there is insufficient street right-of-way for the construction of a required sidewalk, the dedication of an additional right-of-way for street use including a sidewalk and drainage easement shall be required of the developer. The width of the easement shall be determined by the city engineer. A deed of easement for the street right-of-way shall be provided by the property owner to the city in a form approved by the city attorney, and shall stipulate guarantee public access in perpetuity and be recorded with the appropriate county register of deeds. 
(Ord. No. 6006, § I(94-507), 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 90-188. - ADA and transit requirements. 
    All sidewalks built privately or by the city shall conform to the Americans with Disabilities Act Accessibility Guidelines in effect at the time of construction. 
(Ord. No. 6006, § I(94-508), 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 90-189. - Building permits and certificates of occupancy. 
    No building permits shall be issued by the building official until the sidewalk requirements, as set forth herein, have been met and included in the approved development site plan. Certificates of occupancy shall be issued only after all plan requirements have been met and fully completed. 
(Ord. No. 6006, § I(94-509), 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 90-190. - Alternative method of pedestrian mobility. 
    In certain circumstances it may be desirable that an alternative method of pedestrian mobility be substituted for standard sidewalk construction. These alternative methods can include the installation of walking paths, greenways, bike paths or trails, or similar modes of nonvehicular mobility. Alternative surfaces may be considered for such alternative methods, subject to approval by the city engineer. The following provisions shall apply for the approval of alternative methods for the provision of pedestrian mobility: 
(1)  The property owner shall submit a written request for provision of alternative method of pedestrian mobility to the city engineer. The request shall specify the method proposed as a substitute for sidewalk installation. A site plan depicting the location and dimensions of the alternative method of pedestrian mobility, and any other information deemed necessary by the city engineer shall be included with the request; and 
(2)  The request for an alternative method shall be consistent with the sidewalk plan and shall be submitted to the planning commission for approval or rejection. 
(Ord. No. 6006, § I(94-510), 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 90-191. - Sidewalk reconstruction required. 
    Where a principal structure is constructed or erected along an existing street, sidewalk construction is required along all streets adjacent to that property. If sidewalks exist where development or redevelopment is occurring but their width or condition renders them substandard, in the opinion of the city engineer applying the city's design standards, then the developer of the principal structure shall reconstruct the sidewalk following the guidelines and requirements of this division. 
(Ord. No. 6006, § I(94-511), 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 90-192. - Design deviation. 
(a)  In certain circumstances it may be necessary to adjust the standards for sidewalk construction to conform to the unique characteristics of a site. Economic benefit alone is not sufficient grounds for deviation from the standard for sidewalk construction. Unusual or exceptional topography, physical or natural characteristics must be present at the site to justify a design deviation. Any deviation from established sidewalk design standards must be reviewed and approved by the city engineer. The burden of proof shall be on the applicant to demonstrate that the criteria, set out hereinafter, are satisfied before a design deviation may be granted. In considering a request for design deviation the city engineer and the planning commission shall apply the following criteria, all of which must be satisfied before a design deviation may be granted: 
(1)  There must be exceptional physical conditions such as rock, extreme slope or other natural or manmade obstacles existing; 
(2)  The condition must cause the installation of a standard sidewalk be extremely difficult or prohibitively expensive considering the present or future need for the sidewalk balanced with the additional cost for installation; 
(3)  The design deviation shall be the minimum adjustment necessary and every attempt shall be made to ensure that the needs of pedestrians are accommodated to the maximum extent possible; and 
(4)  The design deviation must not be injurious to the neighborhood or detrimental to the public safety and welfare. 
(b)  A design deviation does not include the waiver of sidewalk construction, unless a fee in lieu of construction permitted under section 90-185 is approved. 
(Ord. No. 6006, § I(94-512), 9-21-2010) 
Secs. 90-193-90-222. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CROSSWALKS, DRIVEWAYS AND CURB CUTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-223. - Inspection of work. 
    Under this article, all work shall be subject to inspection by the public works director during construction and upon completion. The public works director shall be notified by the permittee before concrete is poured or surfacing is applied. 
(Code 1981, § 24-18(e); Code 1998, § 94-96) 
Sec. 90-224. - Responsibilities of public works director. 
(a)  The public works director shall formulate design standards, plans and specifications for the construction of driveway approaches, crosswalks and curb cuts. Separate standard plans and specifications may be required for driveway approaches on paved and unpaved streets and arterials and other streets, whether sidewalks and curbs are in place, and for driveway approaches serving different use classifications or properties, such as residential, commercial or industrial. 
(b)  Where a property owner desires a driveway approach differing from the established standards, that property owner may apply to the public works director setting forth the peculiar, exceptional or extraordinary circumstances or conditions prompting the application. The public works director may approve or reject the application. 
(Code 1981, § 24-18(f); Code 1998, § 94-97) 
Sec. 90-225. - Appeals. 
    An order of the public works director pursuant to this article, including an order revoking a permit or the failure or refusal of the public works director to issue a permit, may be appealed by filing a written notice with the city manager within 15 days after the order is received or refusal communicated. The appellant and the public works director shall be granted a hearing before the city manager. 
(Code 1981, § 24-18(j); Code 1998, § 94-98) 
Sec. 90-226. - General requirements. 
    Driveways shall be constructed in accordance with the standard plans and specifications formulated by the public works director for driveway approaches, including the city design standards and the following: 
(1)  The location of the driveway must not unduly interfere with safety and operations of the street and sidewalk system. 
(2)  The width and radius of the driveway approach must be designed to minimize the effect on normal vehicle traffic, prevent unsafe turning and allow for pedestrian safety. 
(3)  The number of driveways shall be limited to a reasonable number which is consistent with sound transportation planning principles. 
(4)  The spacing between driveways shall allow for safe entrance and exit. 
(5)  The driveway area shall allow for ready egress and ingress without causing a backlog of traffic on city streets. 
(6)  Visibility at the driveway approach, as determined by the director of transportation, must be adequate for safe entrance and exit. 
(7)  Existing and proposed use of the property to be connected by a driveway must be in conformity with traffic, zoning and building ordinances and consistent with the relevant goals of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 24-18(g); Code 1998, § 94-99) 
Secs. 90-227-90-247. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 

Sec. 90-248. - Required. 
    No person shall construct or improve a driveway approach across a sidewalk, parking strip, curb or in or upon another part of a public street or public right-of-way without first obtaining a written permit from the public works director or the state department of transportation (TDOT). 
(Code 1981, § 24-18(a); Code 1998, § 94-126) 
Sec. 90-249. - Application. 
    The application for a permit required under this division shall be in writing upon a form provided by the city and shall contain information showing the location, size and other information which may be required by the public works director. Such application must have a cash deposit with the city sufficient to cover fees. 
(Code 1981, § 24-18(b); Code 1998, § 94-127) 
Sec. 90-250. - Expiration. 
    A permit issued under this division shall expire if work is not started within 60 days or completed within 180 days after issuance of a permit. The public works director may grant up to an additional 180-day extension, and a new permit shall be required before beginning or completing the work. 
(Code 1981, § 24-18(c); Code 1998, § 94-128) 
Sec. 90-251. - Revocation. 
    Under this article, all work shall conform to the design standards, plans and specifications formulated by the public works director. A permit may be revoked if the public works director determines that the work is not being performed according to the requirements as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1981, § 24-18(d); Code 1998, § 94-129) 
Sec. 90-252. - Demolition permits. 
    When a demolition permit is issued for the removal of a building, the points of ingress and egress to serve the new use must comply with the standards set forth in this article. Any driveway or part thereof rendered useless by demolition, remodeling or renovation not in compliance must be removed, at the expense of the developer, and the curbing, parkway, sidewalks, etc., replaced to meet existing city specifications. 
(Code 1981, § 24-18(i); Code 1998, § 94-130) 
Secs. 90-253-90-282. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - GRADES AND PROFILES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to construct, improve streets, sidewalks, public ways, assess costs therefor, T.C.A. § 7-32-101. 

Sec. 90-283. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Grade means , as applied to any street, the elevation above sea level as indicated in section 90-284 of the sidewalk at the building line or curbline as indicated. 
(Code 1981, § 24-83; Code 1998, § 94-191) 
Sec. 90-284. - Base or datum plane; elevation. 
    The base or datum plane to which all levels taken by the director of public works or by the city engineer shall be referred shall be that plane at or near sea level from which the following local benchmark has elevation as follows: elevation 1,206.93, USGS monument at the southeast corner of the property designated as the city public library at the corner of New and Broad Streets. 
(Code 1981, § 24-82; Code 1998, § 94-192) 
Sec. 90-285. - Fixing grade on presentation of profile. 
    Grades shall be fixed by resolution of the board of mayor and aldermen on presentation of a profile showing grades through the street or part of street. 
(Code 1981, § 24-84; Code 1998, § 94-193) 
Sec. 90-286. - Official profiles. 
    Under this article, a profile adopted by the board of mayor and aldermen by resolution upon presentation shall be known as the official profile. Official profiles shall bear endorsements of the mayor, recorder, city manager and the city engineer, showing the facts and dates of their approval by the board of mayor and aldermen. 
(Code 1981, § 24-85; Code 1998, § 94-194) 
Sec. 90-287. - Change of established grade. 
    No grade once established shall be changed except upon resolution by the board of mayor and aldermen. 
(Code 1981, § 24-86; Code 1998, § 94-195) 
Sec. 90-288. - Curb grade higher or lower than centerline of street. 
    On streets or along hillsides where it is necessary for drainage or economy to have the curb grades higher or lower than the centerline of the street, the grades shall be shown on the profile, and the curb grade as well as the street grade shall be established. 
(Code 1981, § 24-87; Code 1998, § 94-196) 
Sec. 90-289. - Conformance to grade when improvements made. 
    No person shall erect any permanent improvement without first obtaining the official grade of the street from the director of public works and adhering to it. 
(Code 1981, § 24-88; Code 1998, § 94-197) 
Secs. 90-290-90-311. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - POLES AND WIRES 

Sec. 90-312. - Applicability to franchises. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to affect the provisions of any grant of franchise. 
(Code 1981, § 24-100; Code 1998, § 94-226) 
Sec. 90-313. - Permit for location. 
(a)  No person operating a public utility or furnishing public service shall locate any pole, wire, conduit, pipe or other apparatus necessary, without first having obtained a permit from the director of public works in writing. 
(b)  The director of public works shall specify in such permit the: 
(1)  Kind, size and height of poles to be used; 
(2)  Height at which all wires must be placed; and 
(3)  Size, location and depth of all pipes or conduits. 
(c)  All permits provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall be subject to the approval of the city manager. 
(d)  A copy of such permit shall be filed with the recorder. 
(Code 1981, § 24-101; Code 1998, § 94-227) 
Sec. 90-314. - Construction to conform to specifications in permit. 
    The construction of lines, pipes and conduits and the erection of poles shall conform in all particulars to the specifications as set forth in the permit required in this article or be forthwith subject to removal. 
(Code 1981, § 24-105; Code 1998, § 94-228) 
Sec. 90-315. - Right of city to use poles. 
    Any permit granted under this article shall be subject to the right of the city, free of charge, to place its fire alarm, telegraph or electric lines upon the poles or through the conduits so permitted to be maintained. 
(Code 1981, § 24-102; Code 1998, § 94-229) 
Sec. 90-316. - Right of city to permit others to use poles or conduits. 
    Any permit granted under this article shall be subject to the right of the city to permit the location of wires or lines by any other person upon such poles or through such conduits, upon the payment or tender to the owner thereof of a reasonable compensation, to be determined by the parties. 
(Code 1981, § 24-103; Code 1998, § 94-230) 
Sec. 90-317. - Erection of poles. 
    On business streets having no parkway and where curbs are set, all poles shall be erected in the sidewalk within or adjoining the curbs. Where there are no curbs, the poles shall be so erected as not to interfere with the gutter or with the curb that may thereafter be set there. No poles shall be set or erected within 15 feet of any fire hydrant. 
(Code 1981, § 24-104; Code 1998, § 94-231) 
Sec. 90-318. - Relocation of poles and conduits. 
    Any holder of a permit under this article shall, at his own expense, remove poles or conduits to other suitable locations whenever ordered to do so by the city manager. 
(Code 1981, § 24-106; Code 1998, § 94-232) 
Sec. 90-319. - Number of poles in block. 
    The number of poles permitted in each block shall be determined by the director of public works. 
(Code 1981, § 24-107; Code 1998, § 94-233) 
Sec. 90-320. - More than one line of poles on street. 
    The director of public works shall not grant permits for more than one line of poles on any street, unless it is not advisable to use two or more lines of wire on the same poles, and he shall endeavor to locate poles where they will be least objectionable. 
(Code 1981, § 24-108; Code 1998, § 94-234) 
Secs. 90-321-90-343. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - EXCAVATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 90-344-90-374. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 

Sec. 90-375. - Required. 
    No person, except in or as incident to the exercise or rights given by franchise, shall obstruct, break or dig up the grounds in any street or other public place without a written permit from the director of public works. 
(Code 1981, § 24-50; Code 1998, § 94-66) 
Sec. 90-376. - Bond or cash deposit prerequisite. 
    No person shall be issued the permit required in this division unless he executes a good and sufficient bond to the city in the sum of $1,000.00, conditioned to save the city harmless on account of any loss or damages resulting from such obstructions or excavations, or without having first deposited a sufficient amount of cash with the city recorder as will, in the opinion of the director, cover the cost of restoring the street to its condition prior to the excavating. 
(Code 1981, § 24-51; Code 1998, § 94-67) 
Sec. 90-377. - Restrictions and limitations. 
    The director of public works is authorized to impose such restrictions and limitations upon a permit issued pursuant to this division as he sees fit for the safety and convenience of the public, including but not limited to the erection of barriers and lights. 
(Code 1981, § 24-52; Code 1998, § 94-68) 
Sec. 90-378. - Restoration of surface. 
    It shall be a condition of every permit issued under this division that the person doing the excavation shall cause the surface excavated to be refilled and tamped and put in as good condition as it was before being opened. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to restore the surface excavated to a condition as good as it was prior to the excavation. 
(Code 1981, § 24-53; Code 1998, § 94-69) 
Secs. 90-379-90-399. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PARADES[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Parades of state national guard have right-of-way in streets, T.C.A. § 58-1-601. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-400. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parade means any march or procession in ordered and close file wherein a collective body of persons are proceeding on foot or by conveyance of any form whatsoever in or upon and along any street or thoroughfare in the city. 
(Code 1981, § 24-121; Code 1998, § 94-261) 
Sec. 90-401. - Violations. 
    Any person violating any section of this article or a parade permit issued pursuant to this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1981, § 24-125; Code 1998, § 94-263) 
Sec. 90-402. - Exceptions. 
    This article shall not apply to funeral processions or actions of a governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Code 1981, § 24-124; Code 1998, § 94-262) 
Sec. 90-403. - Duties of permittees. 
    A permittee under this article shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances of the city, the state and the United States. 
(Code 1981, § 24-122; Code 1998, § 94-264) 
Sec. 90-404. - Public conduct during parades. 
(a)  No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct, impede or interfere with any parade or parade assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade. No driver of a vehicle shall drive between vehicles or persons comprising a parade when such vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. 
(b)  The chief of police shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict parking of vehicles along a highway, street or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The chief of police shall post signs to such effect, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. No person shall be liable for parking on a street unposted in violation of this section. 
(Code 1981, § 24-123; Code 1998, § 94-265) 
Secs. 90-405-90-421. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 90-422. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade unless a permit shall have been obtained from the city manager. 
(Code 1981, § 24-134; Code 1998, § 94-291) 
Sec. 90-423. - Application. 
(a)  A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the city manager on forms provided by the city manager. An application for a parade permit shall be filed with the city manager not less than 14 days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade, except as otherwise provided in this section. 
(b)  The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking permission to conduct such parade. 
(2)  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization and of the organization's authorized representatives and responsible heads of such organization. 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairperson and who will be responsible for its management. 
(4)  The date when the parade is to be conducted. 
(5)  The route to be traveled, the starting and the termination point. 
(6)  The approximate number of persons who and animals and vehicles which will constitute such parade; the type of animals and description of the vehicles. 
(7)  The hours when such parade will start and terminate. 
(8)  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets or other public ways proposed to be traversed. 
(9)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade. 
(10)  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly areas. 
(11)  The interval of space to be maintained between units of such parade. 
(12)  If the parade is designed to be held by and on behalf of or for any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the city manager a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf. 
(c)  The city manager, where good cause is shown, shall have the authority to consider any application which is filed less than 14 days before the date such parade is proposed to be conducted. Waiver of the filing period stated in subsection (a) of this section shall be granted when time is of the essence in the processing of an application. In circumstances where time is of the essence, the time for filing the application shall be waived. For purposes of this subsection, the term "time of the essence" means that unless prompt action is taken upon the application for a permit that the purpose for conducting the parade as requested shall be substantially impaired or defeated by processing the application in the ordinary way. When time is of the essence, an application for a permit under this section shall be considered and processed by the city manager with all deliberate speed as the facts and circumstances of each individual case require. 
(Code 1981, § 24-135; Code 1998, § 94-292) 
Sec. 90-424. - Standards for issuance. 
    The city manager shall issue a parade permit when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route. 
(2)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city. 
(3)  The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of the city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto. 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of or ambulance service to areas contiguous to such assembly areas. 
(5)  The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire. 
(6)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route. 
(Code 1981, § 24-136; Code 1998, § 94-293) 
Sec. 90-425. - Notice of rejection. 
    The city manager shall act upon the application for a parade permit within five days after the filing thereof or sooner if time is of the essence. If the city manager rejects the application, he shall deliver to the applicant within five days after the date upon which the application was filed, or sooner if time is of the essence, a notice of his action, stating his reasons for his denial of the permit. 
(Code 1981, § 24-137; Code 1998, § 94-294) 
Sec. 90-426. - Alternative permit. 
    The city manager, in denying an application for a parade permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within three days after notice of the action of the city manager, file a written notice of acceptance with the city manager. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this article. An applicant whose application for a parade permit has been denied by the city manager is not compelled to accept an alternate parade permit and may appeal as provided in this division. 
(Code 1981, § 24-138; Code 1998, § 94-295) 
Sec. 90-427. - Notice to city officials upon issuance. 
    Immediately upon the issuance of a parade permit, the city manager shall send a copy thereof to the following persons: 
(1)  The board of mayor and aldermen. 
(2)  The chief of police. 
(3)  The city attorney. 
(4)  The fire chief. 
(5)  The director of public works. 
(Code 1981, § 24-139; Code 1998, § 94-296) 
Sec. 90-428. - Contents. 
    Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Starting time. 
(2)  Minimum speed. 
(3)  Maximum speed. 
(4)  Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade. 
(5)  The portions of the streets or public ways to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade. 
(6)  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof. 
(7)  Such other information as the city manager shall deem necessary to the enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1981, § 24-140; Code 1998, § 94-297) 
Sec. 90-429. - Possession. 
    The parade chairperson or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade. 
(Code 1981, § 24-142; Code 1998, § 94-298) 
Sec. 90-430. - Revocation. 
    The city manager shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued under this division upon application of the standards for issuance as set forth in this division. 
(Code 1981, § 24-143; Code 1998, § 94-299) 
Sec. 90-431. - Appeals. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, the term "time of the essence" means that unless prompt attention is paid to the applicant's appeal the time for conducting the parade originally requested in the application will have passed prior to the next regularly scheduled meeting of the board of mayor and aldermen. 
(b)  Any person aggrieved by a decision of the city manager under this division shall have the right to appeal the denial of a parade permit to the board of mayor and aldermen. The appeal shall be taken within three days after receipt of notice of rejection from the city manager and shall have a hearing before the board of mayor and aldermen on its next regularly scheduled meeting. 
(c)  If notice of rejection by the city manager has been received by the applicant and the notice of rejection is received more than seven days before the next regularly scheduled meeting of the board of mayor and aldermen, the aggrieved applicant may, in circumstances where time is of the essence, contact the mayor within three days of receipt of notice of rejection and shall have a hearing before the board of mayor and aldermen at a special called meeting of the board by the mayor to consider the petitioner's appeal. 
(d)  The board of mayor and aldermen shall act upon the appeal no later than three days after its receipt or, when time is of the essence, sooner as the facts and circumstances of the individual case require. 
(Code 1981, § 24-141; Code 1998, § 94-300) 
Chapters 91-93 - RESERVED 
Chapter 94 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Taxes and licenses generally, T.C.A. § 67-1-101 et seq.; levy of municipal property taxes, T.C.A. § 67-5-101 et seq.; collection of delinquent taxes, T.C.A. §§ 6-55-201 et seq., 67-5-2005 et seq.; 1963 Local Option Revenue Act, T.C.A. § 67-6-701 et seq.; Retailers' Sales Tax Act, T.C.A. § 67-6-101 et seq.; municipal privilege tax authorized, T.C.A. §§ 6-55-102, 67-4-501, 67-4-704; Business Tax Act, T.C.A. § 67-4-701 et seq.; local taxation of accommodations for transients and hotel occupancy, T.C.A. § 67-4-1401 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 94-1. - Correction of assessment record. 
    The city recorder shall have power to correct a record of a tax assessment provided by the county tax assessor. 
(Code 1981, § 11-1; Code 1998, § 98-1) 
Sec. 94-2. - Collection of delinquent taxes. 
    The board of mayor and aldermen shall, by resolution each year, direct that delinquent taxes are collected by the city attorney or other attorney designated to conduct such collection for advertisement and sale with delinquent state and county taxes. 
(Code 1981, § 11-2; Code 1998, § 98-2) 
State Law reference- Collection of delinquent taxes, T.C.A. §§ 6-55-201 et seq., 67-5-2005 et seq. 
Sec. 94-3. - Due date for public utility ad valorem taxes. 
(a)  For all public utility properties on which the assessment is levied by the state, the ad valorem tax due date shall be the first day of the month next following the billing of such taxes. 
(b)  The due date for all other ad valorem taxes shall be as set out in the Charter. 
(Code 1998, § 98-3; Ord. No. 4185, § I(11-3), 3-5-1996) 
Sec. 94-4. - Penalty date for public utility ad valorem taxes. 
(a)  For all public utility properties on which the assessment is levied by the state, a penalty as provided in the Charter shall be imposed on the first day of the month next following the due date. 
(b)  The penalty date for all other ad valorem taxes shall be as set out in the Charter. 
(Code 1998, § 98-4; Ord. No. 4185, § I(11-4), 3-5-1996) 
Secs. 94-5-94-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LOCAL OPTION SALES TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Local option sales tax, T.C.A. § 67-6-701 et seq. 

Sec. 94-27. - Levied. 
(a)  As authorized by T.C.A. § 67-6-701 et seq., there is levied a tax in the same manner and on the same privileges subject to the Retailers' Sales Tax Act under T.C.A. § 67-6-101 et seq. which is exercised in the city. The tax is levied on all such privileges at the rate of one-quarter of each dollar subject to the maximums prescribed in such act for privileges exercised in the Hawkins County portion of the city, and at the rate of three-quarters of each dollar subject to the maximums prescribed in such act exercised in the Sullivan County portion of the city, so long as the general state rate continues at 4.5 percent. 
(b)  The tax shall be levied at the rate of 1/12 of the rates levied in the Retailers' Sales Tax Act, T.C.A. § 67-6-101 et seq., for privileges exercised in the Hawkins County portion of the city, and at 3/12 of the state rates for privileges exercised in the Sullivan County portion of the city, if and when the general state rate is reduced to three percent. 
(c)  With respect to industrial and farm machinery as defined in T.C.A. § 67-6-102(8), (12) and with respect to water sold to or used by manufacturers, the tax thereon is imposed at the rate as provided in T.C.A. § 67-6-702. The tax shall not exceed the maximums prescribed by statute on the sale or use of any single article of personal property (see section 94-28), and there is excepted from the tax levied by this section the sale, purchase, use, consumption or distribution of electric power or energy or natural or artificial gas or coal and fuel oil, so long as such exception is required by state law. 
(d)  Penalties and interest for delinquencies shall be the same as provided in T.C.A. § 67-6-516. 
(Code 1981, § 11-13; Code 1998, § 98-31) 
State Law reference- Authority for local levy, T.C.A. § 67-6-702. 
Sec. 94-28. - Removal of single-item limit; application of sales tax rate to basis. 
(a)  The maximum local option sales tax collectible on the sale or use of a single item of personal property as authorized by section 94-27, which levied the local option sales tax for that portion of the city situated in Hawkins County, is removed. 
(b)  The local sales tax at the rate effective in that portion of the city situated in Hawkins County shall apply to the first $1,100.00 on the sale or use of any single article of personal property as provided in T.C.A. § 67-6-702. 
(c)  Future increases in the base beginning on the dates specified in subsection (b) of this section shall be automatic and shall not require further action of the board of mayor and aldermen of the city. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to increase the local option sales tax rate heretofore in effect in the city. 
(Code 1981, § 11-14; Code 1998, § 98-32) 
Sec. 94-29. - Collection. 
(a)  It having been determined by the state department of revenue that it is feasible for this tax to be collected by that department, the determination being evidenced by a local option sales and use tax rules and regulations promulgated by the department of revenue, the department shall collect such tax concurrently with the collection of the state tax in the same manner as the state tax is collected in accordance with the rules and regulations promulgated by the department. The mayor is authorized to contract with the department of revenue for the collection of the tax by the department and to provide in the contract that the department may deduct from the tax collected a reasonable amount or percentage to cover the expense of the administration and collection of the tax. 
(b)  If the tax is collected by the department of revenue, suits for recovery of any tax illegally assessed or collected shall be brought against the city recorder-treasurer. 
(Code 1981, § 11-15; Code 1998, § 98-33) 
Secs. 94-30-94-46. - Reserved.

Sec. 94-47. - Levied. 
    There is levied a business and privilege tax upon merchants and such other vocations, occupations or businesses which are declared by state law to be privileges or taxable by municipalities. Such tax shall be in the maximum amounts authorized by state law. 
(Code 1981, § 11-16; Code 1998, § 98-61)

(Code 1981, § 11-17; Code 1998, § 98-62)

ARTICLE IV. - TRANSIENT OCCUPANCY TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Local taxation of accommodations for transients and hotel occupancy, T.C.A. § 67-4-1401 et seq.; Private Acts of 1981, ch. 46, as amended; Private Acts of 1989, chapter 10; Private Acts of 1995, chapter 132; Private Acts of 2007, chapter 52. 

Sec. 94-70. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Consideration means the remuneration charged to a person, whether or not received, for the occupancy of a hotel as valued in money, whether to be received in money, goods, labor or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, property and services of any kind or nature without any deduction whatsoever. Nothing in this definition shall be construed to imply that consideration is to be charged where the space in a hotel to the transient is complimentary and no consideration is charged to or received from any person. 
    Hotel means any structure or any portion of any structure which is occupied or intended or designed for occupancy by transients for dwelling, lodging or sleeping purposes and includes any hotel, inn, tourist court, tourist camp, tourist cabin, motel or any other place in which rooms, lodgings or similar accommodations are furnished to transients for consideration. 
    Occupancy means the use or possession or right to use or possess any room, lodging or similar accommodation in any hotel for a period of less than 30 continuous days. 
    Operator means a person operating the hotel, whether as owner, lessee or otherwise. 
    Person means any individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, state, trust, business trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate or any other group or combination acting as a unit. 
    Tourism means the planning and conducting of programs of information and publicity designed to attract to the city and its surrounding area tourists, visitors and other persons from outside the area and to encourage, assist and coordinate the efforts of public and private organizations or groups of citizens to publicize the facilities and attractions of the city and its surrounding area. The term "tourism" also means the acquisition, construction and remodeling of facilities useful to the attracting and promoting of the tourist, convention and recreation business. 
    Transient means any person who exercises occupancy or is entitled to occupy any room, lodging or similar accommodation in a hotel for a period of less than 30 continuous days. 
(Code 1981, § 11-85; Code 1998, § 98-91) 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, T.C.A. § 67-4-1401. 
Sec. 94-71. - Administrative and enforcement powers of treasurer. 
    The city treasurer, in administering and enforcing this article, shall have all the powers and duties provided in T.C.A. § 67-1-101 et seq., or as otherwise provided by law for the administration and enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1981, § 11-93; Code 1998, § 98-92) 
Sec. 94-72. - Tax imposed. 
    There is levied, assessed and imposed and shall be paid and collected a privilege tax upon the privilege of occupancy by a transient of space in any hotel, such tax to be paid at the rate of seven percent of the consideration charged by the operator for such occupancy. The tax is to be collected and distributed as provided in this article. 
(Code 1981, § 11-86; Code 1998, § 98-93; Res. No. 96-097, 3-19-1996; Ord. No. 5572, § I, 7-3-2007) 
Sec. 94-74. - Method of collection; refund. 
(a)  The tax levied in this article shall be added by each operator to each invoice or bill prepared by the operator for the occupancy of space in a hotel by a transient. Such invoice is to be given directly or transmitted to the transient, and the tax shall be collected by such operator from the transient and remitted to the city treasurer. 
(b)  A person who has maintained occupancy in a space in a hotel for a period in excess of 30 continuous days shall not be deemed a transient and shall receive from the operator a refund or credit for the tax previously collected from or charged to the person, and the operator shall receive credit for the amount of such tax if previously paid or reported to the city. 
(Code 1981, § 11-87; Code 1998, § 98-95) 
Sec. 94-75. - Remittance to treasurer. 
    The tax levied in this article shall be remitted by all operators to the city treasurer no later than the 20th day of each month next following the collection of such tax. Each operator is required to collect the tax from the transient at the time of presentation of the invoice for such occupancy, whether presentation of the invoice is prior to occupancy or after occupancy, as may be the custom of the operator. If a credit is granted by the operator to the transient, the obligation to the city for such tax shall be that of the operator. 
(Code 1981, § 11-88; Code 1998, § 98-96) 
Sec. 94-76. - Reports to treasurer; audit. 
(a)  The city treasurer shall be responsible for the collection of the tax levied in this article. A monthly tax return under oath shall be filed with the city treasurer by each operator with such number of copies thereof as the city treasurer may reasonably require for the collection of the tax. The report of the operator shall include such facts and information as may be deemed reasonable for the verification of the tax due. The form of the report shall be developed by the city treasurer. The city treasurer shall audit each operator in the city at least once per year and shall report on the audits made on an annual basis to board of mayor and aldermen. 
(b)  For the purpose of compensating the operators in accounting for and remitting the tax levied, each operator shall be allowed two percent of the amount of tax collected and remitted to the city treasurer in the form of a deduction in submitting the report and paying the tax; provided, however, the tax amount due was not delinquent at the time of payment by the operator. 
(Code 1981, § 11-89; Code 1998, § 98-97) 
State Law reference- Collection, refunds and credits, T.C.A. § 67-4-1404. 
Sec. 94-77. - Absorption by operator. 
    No operator of a hotel shall advertise or state in any manner whatsoever, whether directly or indirectly, that the tax levied by this article will be assumed or absorbed by the operator or that it is added to the consideration or that, if added, any part of the tax will be refunded. 
(Code 1981, § 11-90; Code 1998, § 98-98) 
Sec. 94-78. - Delinquent taxes. 
    Under this article, taxes collected by an operator which are not remitted to the city treasurer on or before the due date are considered delinquent. Any operator delinquent in the payment of such taxes shall be obligated to pay interest from the due date at the rate of 12 percent per annum, plus a penalty of one-half percent for each month or fraction thereof that such taxes are delinquent. Such interest and penalty shall become a part of the tax. Each occurrence of willful refusal of an operator to collect or remit the tax or willful refusal of a transient to pay the tax imposed is declared to be unlawful and shall be punishable upon conviction by a fine not in excess of $50.00. Such fine shall be levied for each transaction involving the payment of consideration for occupancy of a space in a hotel. 
(Code 1981, § 11-91; Code 1998, § 98-99) 
State Law reference- Delinquencies, T.C.A. § 67-4-1408. 
Sec. 94-79. - Preservation of records. 
    Every operator of a hotel shall keep and preserve for a period of three years, a record of the occupancy of a hotel in order that the city treasurer may determine the amount of the tax levied under this article. The city treasurer shall have the right to inspect such records at all reasonable times. 
(Code 1981, § 11-92; Code 1998, § 98-100) 
State Law reference- Records, T.C.A. § 67-4-1409. 
Sec. 94-80. - Illegal, contested assessments. 
    Upon any claim of illegal assessment or collection of the tax levied in this article, an operator of a hotel shall have the remedy provided in T.C.A. § 67-1-911, and the city treasurer shall possess those powers and duties provided in T.C.A. § 67-1-707 with respect to the adjustment and settlement with taxpayers of all errors of taxes collected under this article and to direct the refunding of such taxes. Notice of any tax paid under protest by an operator shall be given to the city treasurer, and suit may be brought for recovery of such tax paid under protest by filing the suit against the city recorder/treasurer. 
(Code 1981, § 11-94; Code 1998, § 98-101) 
Sec. 94-81. - Disposition of collected funds. 
(a)  The proceeds from the tax levied by this article shall be retained by the city and distributed as follows: 
(1)  871/2 percent of the proceeds shall be used for the direct promotion of tourism and tourism-related activities; 
(2)  121/2 percent of the proceeds shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(b)  No proceeds from any tax collected from this article may be used to provide a subsidy in any form to any hotel. 
(Code 1981, § 11-95; Code 1998, § 98-102) 
State Law reference- Designation of proceeds, T.C.A. § 67-4-1403. 
Chapters 95-97 - RESERVED 
Chapter 98 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Traffic generally, T.C.A. § 55-1-101 et seq.; authority of municipality to regulate traffic, T.C.A. § 55-10-307 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 98-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means a minor street or highway, which affords a secondary means of vehicular access to the back or side of properties otherwise abutting a street and not intended for the purpose of serving through vehicular traffic. 
    Authorized emergency vehicle means such fire department and fire patrol vehicles, police vehicles or bicycles and such emergency vehicles as are designated by the chief of police, and vehicles operated by commissioned members of the state bureau of investigation when on official business. 
    Bicycle means every device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having two tandem wheels, either of which is more than 20 inches in diameter. 
    Bus means every motor vehicle designed for carrying more than ten passengers and used for the transportation of persons; and every motor vehicle, other than a taxicab, designed and used for the transportation of persons for compensation. 
    Business district means the territory contiguous to and including a highway when within any 600 feet along such highway there are buildings in use for business or industrial purposes, including but not limited to hotels, banks or office buildings, railroad stations and public buildings which occupy at least 300 feet of frontage on one side or 300 feet collectively on both sides of the highway. 
    Commercial vehicle means every vehicle designed, maintained or used primarily for the transportation of property for hire, compensation or profit and registered under T.C.A. § 55-4-113 and, if registered under state law, displaying a commercial vehicle registration certificate. 
    Controlled-access highway means every highway, street or roadway in respect to which owners or occupants of abutting lands and other persons have no legal right of access to or from the highway, except at such points only and in such manner as may be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over such highway, street or roadway. 
    Crosswalk means that part of a roadway at an intersection included within: 
(1)  The connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the highway measured from the curbs or, in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway; or 
(2)  Any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
    Curb loading zone means a space adjacent to a curbline reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials. 
    Curbline means the lateral boundary of that portion of the street designated for the use of vehicles, whether marked by curbstones or not.
